reviewText:
This is a mesmerizing and addictive game.  The idea is not new: design a spaceship, battle other spaceships, mine resources in order to buy ship upgrades, repeat.  But this game stands out for a few reasons.

First is the realism of ship design.  You assemble your ship out of a stock of components in a editor reminiscent of Microsoft Visio (but better; MSFT ought to hire this guy).  In most games like this, you might, say, upgrade to Engine IV, which makes you move at speed 8.  In Reassembly, your ship's behavior is instead calculated as a consequence of your design.  Speed, for example, is a result of your thrust and mass, but in addition, maneuverability is a result of where you put your thrusters, how they're angled, your ship's center of gravity (which is indicated in the ship editor), etc.  If your ship doesn't handle the way you like, it's your fault, and you can easily fix it.

Second is the AI behavior.  All ships seek resources which grow on space rocks.  Lots of small ships hover around these rocks harvesting what they can find; a few medium-size ships prowl around the perimeter hunting the small ships; and occasionally capital ships arrive and destroy everyone.  It feels rather like an ecology simulator, with minnows nibbling at coral reefs, big fish eating the minnows, and so on.  Since the universe is dynamically generated, I assume this 'ecology sim' behavior isn't hard-coded, but is emergent behavior of the ship AI.  Anyway, it makes you feel that you're inhabiting a living world.

It's beautiful, too, with a minimal color palette standing out against stark black space.  Hundreds of ships can be onscreen at a time without the game apparently breaking a sweat (thanks Reassembly developer, for actually caring about performance).  And the trance-y music complements the minimalist esthetic nicely.

If you built Lego spaceships as a kid, or you have scuba dived in a coral reef and liked it, you should play this game.

reviewText:
Upon trying this out, I really did not know what to expect. At first, however, I found myself a little lost in this strangely organic world that is somewhere in the far reaches of space.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=swxfEZJtZAk
It doesn't take long for you to realize that you are not alone, and, in fact, you have a whole faction that shares your own desire for expansion in the untamed universe. Unlike many in this loose genre, you fight side by side with your AI friends from beginning to end.

Make no mistake, this is, at it's core, a block building game, where you build your spaceship, and can build fleets of custom ships to fight with you or just let them loose to go it on thier own. Where they will build more ships of thier own and fight the good fight for the faction gathering resources and growing your empire just like yourself. In many ways, when I play this I feel like just another small, but important, peice of a larger hive doing my part. Although I would like to think that I might contribute a little more than my AI companions, I hope.

In Reassembly, you will explore, expland, exploit, and exterminate. Yes, this is, in fact, a 4X game, hidden underneath a very well crafted version of a top down space shooter.

The more I play, the more I want to play, and I find myself losing time. It's worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reassembly is one of those games you find hidden in broad daylight, a gem in a sea of hyped up fast paced fps games.

And boy is it a gem. The kind where it will suck you in for hours if you're not careful. As it is now in its beta phase, some new features are now part of the game. Most notably asynchronous Multiplayer.

This does not mean players will directly fight other players. Rather, it is still single player in that retrospect. What you do fight, are the ships that other players have spent countless hours, or a few seconds throwing together, in a big mashup found dotted about in the ecosystem.

You will find many different tactics and build strategies are required to best some of the more difficult enemies, and ultimately, your goal will be universal annihilation!! MWAHAHA!! Or at least that's my goal.

You can either wander aimlessly, killing everything you see, avoiding everything you see, copying everything, building everything, or just plain sit there while you watch hordes of allied AI ships, drones, and missiles beat the crap out of your foes in shiny balls of explosions!

There is a relatively small but lively community found on this game's forums, where the Developer himself, Arthur, runs and frequents.

One more thing! Every few weeks, there are design contests held where players can create ships to blow each other up in a big tournament! Further excitement is based solely on player discrecion.

Update! I forgot to mention some stuff

There are currently over 500 different parts, the player has direct access to about 40 of them. (the others are parts from other factions, of which there are 15)

You can fly around and kill things, design ships, and collect resources. There isn't much of a story mode, but there is a sandbox where you can spawn any faction and build with every part. (requires a basic level of coding knowledge)

The ai is incredibly smart. There are ai competitions every few weeks where players build ships to a certain danger level, then submit them to different classes, where they fight to the death round robin style, and the best 16 are pitted in a single elimination bracket for all to see.
From these tournaments, the developer (Arthur) works on tweaking the ai so that it can better fend for itself during battles, leading to more aggressive enemies.
The current system of ai smarts has to do with profile tags that are randomly assigned to each ai, some will get a bad aim" tag
recommended: and any combination of tags will eventually result in harder enemies. The hardest so far is one that has tags "smart fire

reviewText:
***Written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

Reassembly is a 2D spaceship building game that is currently available through Steam Early Access. In Reassembly you use materials you find all around you in an area of deep space to upgrade and modify your ship using a number of parts available to you. Reassembly can be enjoyed in three different game modes which I will briefly explain now.

First off we have the main game mode (it doesn't have a specific name), in the main game mode you take control of a ship in a huge, procedurally generated, sector of deep space. You start in a friendly area where you can also find other ships who are fighting on your side and can be recruited to join you in battle though they will help you anyway. As you travel through this area of space you will fight enemies from many factions and repair space stations which exchange R (resource points) for C (currency) so that you can purchase upgrades and new parts.

Next we have the tournament mode. Here you can choose any of the ships you have created (or any you have downloaded though I'm not sure where you get them from) and then you watch them go head to head to see which ship is better. The number of ships you select for your tournament effects how many rounds take place and a winner is crowned at the end of each round.

Finally we have the sandbox mode. I'm going to be honest here, I have absolutely no idea what this is, you start with a blank map (apart from some welcoming words) and a text box at the top in which you have to enter lines of code to do something though I couldn't tell you what that something is as I have no idea what kind of code it uses.

Unless I state otherwise the following positives and negatives are for the main game mode.

+Gorgeous, colourful vector graphics
+The map is procedurally generated for each save slot so you can never play the same game twice
+When your ship is damaged it takes parts of debris from surrounding space to repair itself and watching parts of your ship get repaired is really quite cool
+You aren't alone in your mission, you always have a faction of ships who are friendly and can be recruited into your fleet
+Once you get the hang of it (I'll come to that later) the building system this game has allows you to create really cool things and if you gradually add things, piece by piece, it's possible to make great things even if you aren't particularly creative
+Lots of different enemy factions, enemy factions fight each other as well as your faction
+Different factions have very different ship designs and they all have their own strengths and weaknesses
+When you are destroyed you spawn at a nearby, friendly space station
+The universe feels alive as you frequently come across battles between enemy factions
+Watching two ships fight in the tournament mode is really cool and quite relaxing since you aren't in control
+You have nine save slots to play around with
+Great soundtrack though it does get repititive after a while
+Good sound effects

+/-Reassembly has wormholes which allow your ships to travel into other players' game and vice versa which is a great idea, sady it is executed poorly. This mechanic puts the game's balance six feet under as you frequently find yourself facing ships thousands of times more powerful than your own early on in the game which of course you stand absolutely no chance against

-Nothing in the game is explained to the player apart from a couple of basics at the beginning, you're left to figure out things like building and the upgrade system all by yourself
-Reassembly requires a lot of grinding, especially early on. I found myself going around destroying asteroids and small ships just to get enough R and C to unlock new parts so that I actually stood a chance against small ships at which point the cycle resets and grinding begins again
-The controls take a lot of getting used to and 4 hours in I'm still struggling with them
-There seems to be a lot of unnecessary drifting, even when you respawn you instantly start drifting in seemingly random directions
-The Sanbox mode is not explained at all and doesn't look overly user friendly
-I feel like it's really missing Steam Workshop intergration, being able to share ships easily would make the tournament game mode much more fun
-As far as I can tell there is no overall objective apart from destroying ships to make your own more powerful

Verdict:
7

A good 2D space building game with a lot of potential and a rich universe which is let down by its current lack of instruction and the amount of grinding.

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short Version:

Crack. Heroin. Nicotine. Alchohol. Reassembly. What do these things have in common? They're all highly addictive. With that being said, Reassembly deffinately has it's faults, but if their's something that interests you about this game, then it's probly worth checking out.

Long Version:

Reassembly is a 2d, top down, vector graphic space shooter that lets you build your own fleet to conquer the galaxy with. You start out the game with a few premade ships to select from, a faction that looks just like you, and a galaxy full of things that want to kill you. Your objectives are to capture space stations, gather raw resources, turn them into your faction for credits, use those credits to research new parts and upgrade the power of your ship. The further into the galaxy you go, the harder it gets. Whilst exterminating all life that isn't allied to you from the galaxy, you use the very easy to use ship builder to customize or build from scratch both your ship, and your allied ships. (They either automatically spawn based on designs from your inventory, or are spawned by you from a factory ship.) When designing a ship, you can also elect to 'test' your ship in a series of 1v1 ai controlled deathmatches, exactly like the anisoptera contests.

Then there's the asynchronus multiplayer, this game's greatest feature, and biggest pitfall. Essentially, ships that other players have designed will be found strewn throughout the galaxy, in their own factions. Typically, these factions are far stronger than any of the vanilla factions you will encounter, however, that's not true of all of them. For example, one user created a troll ship in the sandbox mode, which allows ship designs that aren't legal in the normal game mode. Only now, here's that ship in _my_ normal game mode. I have a problem with that. Further compounding this problem, are the contest ships. Those ships are purpose built to fall into a specific category of ship, and dominate anything with the same power level or below. Sounds about right, doesn't it? I mean, isn't that the whole point of the contest, and ship design in general? The problem is, you're playing a game that isn't a 1v1 deathmatch. You need storage tanks for your raw resources, factories to spawn your death fleet, and just in general use components that take up space that could be used for more killing devices, or maneuverability. For example, one ship I came across was designed to ram into you, shove a ton of armor between you and his control module, while having 6 plasma cannons on these fragile little arms. The idea being, there's no way for you to chew through his armor before those untouched cannons melt your entire ship. This works great in those ai controlled deathmatches, however it's completely useless in the main game. I'd like to see all sandbox ships blocked from the main game, as well as a user set flag in the designer for competition mode" or some such
date: where any ships that have that flag aren't used for the main game.\n\nI've come across few other issues
recommended: like occasionally getting stuck in other objects when changing your ship (solved with a relog) and minor bugs.\n\nAn early access game
hoursPlayed: and my complaints are fairly minor in nature? Why are you still reading? Go forth and buy immediately! ;)"

reviewText:
So I've got about 100 legitimate hours of playing this game. That's split between playing the singleplayer, building ships for tournaments, watching my ships compete in tournaments, and sharing and battling ships with friends.

This is, in all honesty, one of the best space-ship games I've ever played. The game itself is built on very simple components: simple physics, simple graphics, and simple 2-D exploration. However, it is the way these parts fit together under the fantastic music and brilliant vector-based combat that just draw you in. Very immersive, very fun, very addicting, and by far the best ship builder in any space game I've ever played. The ship builder and sharing tools are really the highlights of the game.

What there is to do:
-Build ships from scratch
-Fly ships in open 2D space
-explore procedurally generated content (As with all games that rely on procedurally generated content, the wow factor goes away pretty fast. Thankfully, this isn't what the game relies on to stay fun)
-Unlock new ship pieces and build better ships out of the scrap of your defeated foes.
-Build a factory and begin constructing a fleet
- Battle fleets made by other players at hotly contested wormholes (There is no multiplayer, but the AI is VERY good and it pilots the fleets that players themselves upload. It priotizes the fleets made by steam friends)
-Enter the wormhole to upload your fleet
-share ship.lua files with friends and pit them in 1v1 battle in tournament mode to see who can make the best ship.
-7 playable factions

That's about it. One last note, it seems that the developer is pretty much done with the game. There haven't been any major patches since the launch and the forum activity has died down quite a bit, but I believe the last thing that's being set up for this game is compatibility with steam workshop so that all future content will come from the game's players rather than the devs.

reviewText:
If you like Battleships Forever or Captain Forever, this game is for you. (They're both freeware so go try them if you're interested in this.) It takes the concepts of both, and throws in a bit of Starsector (namely the fleet mechanics) for good measure to make a game I've poured hours into already. (As of writing, I've played it for 10.8 hours. I bought it yesterday.)

While some have also compared it to Gimbal, I'd say only at the very start. The comparison starts losing ground once you get the bigger ships.

Where this stands out is the.. well, game. BF and CF are both fun for a short play, but don't have many backing gameplay mechanics. Reassembly gives you economies, waring fations, fleet control and quite a bit of variety (Though I'd like to see mod support in the future for even more pieces/factions). Each faction also plays differently in various ways, for example, one can plant and grow their own resources, but seem to be lacking in firepower, another has literal nukes, but no shields, and so on, it forces a change in tactics when it comes to ship design that keeps things fresh. With all that in mind, it's still a sandbox, outside of the tutorial, what you do is purely up to you with zero guidance, I personally like that, some might not.

It should also be noted it seems to run superbly. I have a fairly powerful machine, but any game with 1000s of ships/particles will slow it down some. This doesn't, I've had fleets of hundreds of ships facing off against each other, and it has stayed at a stable 60fps.

All in all, one of the best games I've purchased in a very long time.

EDIT: Apparently mod support is already somewhat in the game. I got ahead of myself.

reviewText:
In my opinion, this is the best purchase I've made all year.

Synopsis:

You fly ships and blow things up, exploring new sectors and conquering the universe. You collect resources.  You upgrade your blueprints and your power level" to build bigger
date: better ships.\n\nEventually you can build "factories" on your ships
recommended: which allow your ships to produce even more ships. These ships become part of your "fleet"
hoursPlayed: allowing you to get into bigger
voteText:
better fights.

Upgrades are permanent. Possibilities are almost endless.



What I love:
1) Few restrictions are imposed on designs. Making ships is a blast. Learn the shortcuts.

2) Factions and weapons vary well. Each has strengths and flaws. There is no magic bullet.

3) The learning curve to designing ships is rewarding. You will quickly discover what doesn't work.

reviewText:
Edit (3/21/16): It's been 4 months. Looking at my stats it says: 51 products, 1 review, 1400+ hours; I know what you're thinking... DO NOT CALL 911, I have assuredly not been taken hostage by this game. I just happened to leave the program running 24/7 every now and then. There is totally nothing to worry about (please don't judge me!)...

I have found that most of this game's replayability lies in (1) - creating and enjoying the diverse player-created mods and (2) - pitting ship designs against each other in competitions amongst friends as a frantic cry for help

Mods are incredibly easy to work with (using and creating) and can be downloaded or turned on/off with minimal hassle. With absolutely zero bias none whatsover, for a quick graphics spruce-up, you can visit my graphics-upgrade mod at http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=644263599

Actual Review (12/10/15):I've always had a soft spot for the build-your-own-spaceship genre. I enjoyed Captain Forever, Battleships Forever, Gimbal,  as well as Stardrive 2. I have no idea how I didn't find out about it until now.

I think Reassembly takes the great construction and space combat elements of all those games and puts it in one solid package. I was surprised to see it run smoothly during heavy action (unlike Stardrive), In its category, the decent amount of gameplay depth and accessibility help make this one a top tier 2D-space-builder-shooter. Sure there's some things that need fixing (such as the tutorial checklist showing up every time a new game is started) but even so I would wholeheartedly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of Beta build from Nov 26:
Reassembly is kind of the game that takes one and only one thing and does it very very well. In this case it's crazy custom ship skirmishes.
Target of the game is pretty simple - conquer the whole map. And all you have to accomplish that is you own ship, some raw resources and a couple of supporting space stations.
You have to farm (literally, they grow on space plants) resources, fight enemies, build your fleet and slowly proceed to the center of the map. That's a game in a nutshell. But, I want to stress this once more, the game does this one thing very VERY good.
Add here a nice async multiplayer - all players can share their ship builds online, and those shared ships will appear in other players' games. Which is pretty awesome if ask me.
But is it enough? Well, that's for you to decide. If you ask me - it definitely is.
Oh, and don't forget the amazing soundtrack!

More detailed look in the video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VG-RP0yBg8M

reviewText:
Of all the space, building, sandbox, and customizable games I've played, this one is way up in my top favorites. For those who love to be creative, this game is a must-get.

PROS:
+ Full customization of ships and stations, shape by shape. This is a huge plus for those who love to build things from the ground-up.
+ Ship building is very well structured and stable. Rarely are there frustrating moments where blocks don't do what I want.
+ Semi-open world (the world loops, but you can travel to new maps too.)
+ Nice graphics & well-built. Nothing too fancy, but still fitting. This game isn't too demanding in general, in terms of hardware.
+ Easy to get the hang of. It doesn't take too long to figure things out.
+ Forgiving gameplay. If you die, you lose all your resources that you were carrying, but if you're nearby enough, you might be able to rush back to pick it up.
CONS:
- Frustrating at times. There will be times when you have those BS" moments
recommended: it gets rather annoying sometimes.\n- Trial-by-fire learning curve. I advise against going to the center of the map until you're at max build limit...\n- Full customization. For those who aren't able to commit to building your entire ship
hoursPlayed: there are only a few pre-made ships available at the start. Again

reviewText:
This game was a weird experience. It looks like a RTS, but plays like a 2D action game. It gives you the feeling of an ant in an anthill, fighting against the minions of other swarms. But also you grow and evolve and start to get your own swarm, that follows you.
All in all, beside being a space shooter, it really has some organic feeling. It also could be on the bottom of the ocean. Or maybe small microorganisms.

Your ship is made of different shaped geometric objects. Hull parts, interior and weapons. Zoomed out, they give surprisingly good looking shapes. After you design your first ship, you are thrown in a crazy living 2D world, where everything tries to kill you, that has a different color than you. This isnt always user friendly. Flying too early too far out of your territory you face enemys, that are 10 times the size of you. While you explore, you unlock commando points, that give you new weapons or upgrading your ship to be able to use more parts to be bigger. Also your surroundings generate ressources. Everyone is gathering them. If you kill an enemy, he will drop his ressources, if you die, they will also loot you. You can turn in those ressources on allied bases to get more commando points, also that station will generate new allied ships. That way, every faction on the map is constantly growing at attacking the borders of the other faction.
As the game continues, you will find more and more ressources, unlock new weapons, until you are that big, that you stop selling your ressources but generating your own minions, that follow you. If they are big enough and have a factory, they also will be able to gather ressources and build ships.
If you are bored with your universe, you take your fleet and go to a new one (reset the game, like a new game+).

Every enemy faction has unique weapons, buildings, ships and tactics. Some of them can be really annoying, most of them are playable, after you once defeated them.

While working perfectly (I only had one massive crash), the game has a lot of flaws that bug me:
- there is no real war: The world only moves around you. If you arent present, the areas arent loaded. That way, you only have the illusion of a living world, but the only acting thing is you.
- enemy AI is korean like, allied AI is on drugs: Having some maxed out follower ships, then seeing them flying into an enemy fleet like idiots and dying like idiots makes you question the game. Seeing the enemy flying player designed ships better than the player is capable of, makes you rage a lot. It is no fun fighting the AI. They will dash forward, attack you and retreat like cowards, when you fire back. That way, a lot of small ships are capable of slowly poking you to death. If you manage to hit them, they will run away, like on crack, never giving you the chance of actually destroy and loot them. Some ships, even split in half and totally destroyed managed to escape me with 1 or 2 remaining thrusters and the commando bridge. A strong AI is cool and challenging. A perfect AI, that plays safe and never do mistakes is frustrating. A lot! Its not about them being OP, its about them always fleeing a fight.
- Charging my lazerz: directed beam weapons > everything. You can defeat 90% of the map by using massive amounts of the charge beam laser. Then put it on point defence. Then laugh like an idiot watching those skirmishing ships flying towards you to do their stupid hit and run, seeing them exploding because your point defence automatically targets and destroy them. Your other weapons will be massive amounts of plasma cannon to melt down everything that cant move away, or, if you like it with more precision, gaus rifles to shoot those poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s without them even knowing from where you hit them.
- After reaching max size, the game is over. There is nothing to do. Even the big ships, that chased you in the beginning, are small fishes now. I even managed to cut one of them in half with a single salve of gaus shots. Since you have the lasers, you dont have to care about the small ones ether. Simply ignore them. They will come in weapon range, then explode.
- If you are bad at designing and crafting games, just dont.

Reassembly is not a decent game, it is an awesome game! But has major problems with balancing, AI, mapping and simply has no endgame.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Essentially, if we all think back to the games we played long ago most of us will remember a game where the player controlled a small and weak little fish. Your aim in this game was to swim around in the ocean and eat any of the fish small enough to fit in your mouth and then hall ♥♥♥ away from fishes that were large enough to eat you in one go.

That is a game i feel thay Reassembly can quite easily be compared to. You start off with a small array of 'stock' ships, provided by the dev team to get you started. These are your small fish. As the game provides you with tutorial messages and objectives you will fail at killing a couple of ships as you get used to the aiming and flying mechanics and you will find that if the ship is smaller than yours... It blows up. The moment you see a ship that consists of a number of blocks higher than yours. Run. Or more likely get blown up and respawn.

But as you kill the little ships and gather your resource, convert it into C and then purchase upgrades or convert it into P. Your ship begins to grow. You test out designs but eventually you realise as long as you make it big and fast and cover it in as many guns you can hide beneath shields... You're doing the a good job. Your ship begins to get larger... You can kill larger ships... Your ship gets larger still. You begin ignoring the smaller craft you once relied on for resources as they are just a minor neusance to you. You feel like a God amongst the stars. Then a Scythe ship one shots you and you start farming those little guys again just to boost your ego back up.

Great game, very long review. Essentailly Hungry Fish with lasers and 'spolsions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a normal format for my reviews; I will eschew it for Reassembly. Normally I speak of a game's good, bad and ugly qualities, in hopes of bringing excitement for the games perks, and light to its flaws.

I can give this game no higher praise but to say this: I can find no faults in it. The game is brilliantly executed, if perhaps still limited, but then I haven't beaten the game yet. The exploration draws you in in a way that I was utterly surprised by. Since the first day of exploring this title, I have been eager to resume it, to stretch my ship building talents, to bring vengeance to the evil red ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who always seem to be one step ahead.

The music is nothing short of masterful. Most of the time I tire of the music and mute it in favor of my normal playlists, but the soundtrack is so beautifully atmospheric that there is no need.

Now let's speak of the elephant in the room, a two headed monstrosity. The first head is the game's graphics. From it's trailer, you have accurately seen the game's aesthetics, and they are indeed simple. Then, you have the $40 price tag, a cost very near a AAA title. I showed this game to a roommate who immediately got sucked in, but when he saw the price, said, Well
date: maybe I'll get it if it goes on sale."\n\nTake a look at this game's reviews thus far. It scarcely has more than 30
recommended: but EVERY SINGLE ONE of them is positive. I have never seen a 100% approval rating on steam. I take from this two things: For those with the means
hoursPlayed: you WILL enjoy this title. I guarantee it. Two: It is beyond what most people would reasonably expect to pay.\n\nFor a delivery system that has no manufacturing
helpfulPercent: and still in early access

votesTotal: its sales would SKYROCKET
votesFunny: by much more than double.\n\nThat being said
commentsCount: with EVERYTHING that I said
column16: this game is WORTH the forty dollars."

reviewText:
Fantastic little game, but of course it has its flaws too.

First off, basically everything about this game is something to love, the graphics are really simple but work so damn well, the framerate NEVER drops below 60, the sound and music are also simplistic but lovely and the gameplay is some really incredibly fun stuff!

At the start, the game throws a ton of mechanics at you. Once you either get a friend to explain it to you or re-read all texts a few times, you'll get what the different terms mean, get used to them and be able to work with them.

While I imagined the gameplay to get repetitive at some time, it actually stayed incredibly fresh and fun for all this time. You keep getting new ideas on what to do, new things to try out, you can keep expanding and if all's boring, just start a new game in a different faction, changing up the gameplay a TON.

The other thing is: you NEED a good upload speed to play this game, because once you close it, it has to sync about 20MB of data (the world and ships) to the Steam Cloud, stopping you from playing other games during that time, and is just plain annoying. The even worse bit is that DISABLING Steam Cloud syncing seems to erase all ships you've created (it at least happened for me, not sure if that's exactly the cause), so you gotta deal with it somehow...

EITHER WAY, this game is so damn awesome, please go play it, I'll tell ya, once you get used to the mechanics, it'll be an enormous time sink!

reviewText: I don't know if I'm the only one who did this, so I ask: Did you like creating impressive, huge ships in Lego and make them battle (using your imagination, of course)? Well, now you can do it for real, on a game that actually creates the battles for you (Imagination is overrated). With no true plot (You are part of a faction, you battle every other faction. That's basically it.) and no central objective, Reassembly is just pure fun. You design your ship with parts that actually have a significant impact in how your ship moves, fires and defends, and you battle other ships, some even designed by other people.\n\nI had a blast playing this game, and spent my whole day experimenting with different weapons and factions, balancing my fleet, spending credits to make my ship bigger and bigger, and dying because my ship was too fast and bumped against a wall, causing instant explotions. If that sounds fun, then by all means, play this game. You'll love it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have over a hundred hours put into this game, my steam game time is off.


This beautiful diamond amongst rock, is literally the perfect game for those who possess creativity, and love to simply immerse themselves into a game that rewards for said effort contributed unto it.

I have played Hundreds upon Hundreds of rpg's, sandbox's, adventure and action gerne etc.
This Masterpiece took the elements from many of the games I held dear, and assimilated them all into a free spirited sandbox rpg with not just replayability, but literally the best customization and diversity i've ever seen in an rpg/sandbox.

This game is simple. In said simplicity, there is an elaborate but gradual growth of complexity. The complex part of this game is the factor that you, as a player, control. This factor is your ship! Along with the other ships in your fleet. The more complex and functional you make your ship, the more beautiful it/they may become without you even realizing it.

Having made over a hundred ships, I can vouch for the ship creation system, as it is somewhat pleasing to invest ten minutes to have an exquisite and awe'ing ship emerge :)


Please! If you are contemplating whether or not to invest in this game, let the reviews and hours do the talking!

It's worth the money.

reviewText:
Kickstarted this game because it looked awesome.

Essentially, procedurally-generated (and with wormholes, basically infinite) shmup with a focus on customizing your ship. It gives you basically lego-style building blocks (e.g. square or triangular hull blocks) plus various components like your ship's core, harvesters, storage, etc. as well as a plethora of increasingly fun weapons to use. Once you have your ship, you simply fly out and battle all the ships in the world -- this isn't procedurally generated, but the devs made a huge number of ships, and it'll take ships other players made and put them in your world, so there's a lot to blow up.

Overall, and excellent and really replayable game.

reviewText:
So, I love the idea of this game, and hope it gets multiplayer in the future, but I have a few problems with it:
1. Ships can be made insanely fast, too fast for most weapons to even have a chance of hitting.
2. All turrets have the ability to turn 360 degrees, making ship design as simple as slapping as many guns into an armored ball.
3. Engines can be inside your ship, meaning there is no way to damage them without first destroying the components around them.
I love how the building works, but I feel like there's still a lot of balancing that needs to be done, since the meta just dictates blobbing up as many guns as you can fit with either:
a. ♥♥♥♥♥ons of armor (which is entirely free most of the time, so you could make a massive armored box at the very beginning)
b. ♥♥♥♥♥ons of engines, making you pretty much impossible to hit with anything but lasers (although the speed is best put into use by the AI controlled ships, since they can instantly dodge out of the way of almost any attack)

I love this game, but I hope it gets the things I mentioned.

Edit: I just also need to add that the only part of your ship that the AI shoots is your core, so it is optimal to leave extruding parts of your ship unarmored...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reassembly is an excellent mix of 2D space combat, spaceship building, exploration and resource gathering.

In the Beta you start with a small group of ships to choose from, which you can totally ignore and build your own if you desire. As you blow up enemy ships and explore you can choose to increase the limit of how big your ship can be and/or unlock more powerful components. You start on the edge of the galaxy where it's relatively safe, as you explore towards the center the enemies become bigger and way more powerful.

There are wormholes you can fly into. These will either take you to a fresh galaxy or send an AI controlled copy of your ship to other player's galaxies. My goal is not only to take over my own galaxy but be the bane of other galaxies as well :)

The ecosystem" in Reassembly reminds me of microscopic organisms growing

reviewText:
Creativity in video games has always been a standard. How do you beat this next boss? How do you navigate past this obstacle? In the past, the solution usually had a few different answers, but today the answers offered really do seem endless. Reassembly demostrates this by placing you in a gigantic galactic sandbox. You will start as the little fish, and work your way into becoming a devastating war-machine. Do you prefer anti-matter cannons, or a nice simple plasma beam? Maybe you will swarm the enemies with missiles and drones. Maybe even all of the above! Eventually you will also get the opportunity to design and produce your own fleet with a factory attachment. Each ship can be given a “child order” in which they will spawn their own new ships as long as they too have a factory attached. A war-machine and a loving mother? Oh the duality of man… Er, woman… Err… Spaceship. This isn’t going well. Anyways, let’s take a closer look at Reassembly.

Upon killing an enemy ship you will start to gain “R” or resources, which can then be traded in for “C” (currency). The currency is then used to buy new parts that can be used in any new ship design, this means you will probably redesign your ships fairly regularly to keep up with the latest, greatest weapons in attempts to conquer bigger threats. Your mothership has a “P” limit, I assume P is for power, which can be upgraded with the currency. The power limit of any ship designs constructed will translate to the resource cost once you eventually unlock the factory. While the basics can take a while to master due to the needlessly abbreviated names, eventually your mother-ship will be ready to take on anything. You will scoot around repairing damaged stations, which are actually destroyed by your enemies in real time! There are 7 factions, which means 6 different races to destroy! While you might enjoy feeding on their little guys, stay on your guard because there is almost always a bigger fish. Then again, it might be worth the risk because destroying one of the gigantic capital ships among their allied swarm is extremely thrilling!

Maintaining control of an entire galaxy is tough work though, and opposing factions aren’t the only ones out to ruin your rampage. Agent fleets, which are created and uploaded by other users (via wormholes) will relentlessly hunt down and destroy your spawning stations. When you finally find your way back to try and repair it, prepare for one hell of a fight. Flight and weapons are wonderfully dynamic, both in combat and out. Navigating an asteroid field takes a lot of foresight, unless you just have a set of lasers mounted to burn through anything that gets in your way. Some weapons are able to follow your cursor, while others are mounted firmly to the ship. Finding the best combination for your race, fleet, and strategy is absolutely imperative. Each of the seven races offers a completely unique set of parts for their ships so even after you’ve cleaned up the galaxy as one team, there is still tons of incentive to go back and try the others. The AI is pretty intelligent as well. You won’t see a drone ship (yours or the enemy’s) rush into the fray, and even the combat fighters know when it’s time to retreat.

There is very little criticism I’m able to find for Reassembly. It does lack a story, and the level generation seems completely random which doesn’t lead to much strategy regarding which colored enemies to go after until later in the game when territories have more or less been established. Overall, I found Reassembly to be an endlessly replayable treat, with a learning curve much higher than one would perceive at first glance. There are so many little touches that put this game over the top, such as the ship building battle simulator, in which you can test your newly constructed ship against enemies of around the same cost. This helps immensely with knowing how the AI will handle the many ships you spawn for it. Paired with the amazing construction, and as many galaxies as there are wormholes to crawl through (read: ENDLESS) this game is a fantastic indie gem that has truly blessed my library. Big thanks to Anisoptera Games and Indie Voyage for the review copy, this game is a jump away from absolute perfection. Fantastic work!

Gameplay:

Controls- 9/10
Fun Factor- 10/10
Difficulty- 9/10
Replayability- 10/10
Innovation- 9/10

Aesthetic:

Graphics- 9/10
Music- 7/10
Sound FX- 8/10
Story/Lore- 5/10
Level Design- 6/10

Final Score: 84/100 for fun factor, replayability, and graphics.
Summary: A gorgeous space-sandbox which allows you to design your own fleet and strategy.
Verdict: Reassembly will please anyone with an eye for construction and customization.

Gameplay/Review video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GO65vyQ9IVQ
Full text/photo review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-reassembly/

reviewText:
I am REALLY amazed about this game. This game absolutely nails the playability and usability. For me this game is up there with FTL and Minecraft, where you can just keep playing and playing for the fun of the experience itself, not the winning.

The building of new spacehips, trying out combinations, and just trying to make things look good is a lot of fun. Combined with the amazing slickness of the editor you can spend hours in a Zen-like mode of tweaking, playing, and tweaking some more.

What sets this game apart as well is that you fight the creations of other players, and that others will play against yours. That makes you care about your creations much more than you would have in a purely single player game.

All in all highly recommended if you like 2D space shooters and building games.

reviewText:
A fun enjoyable game with endless playtime, although it can be grindy at times if you play your cards right (easy) grinding will only take 1-3 minutes, just add more time to that for the extra currency/resources you need.
Graphics are simplistic yet easy to get around, nothing overly high  1800x1800 pixel sprite sheets like most other games out right now so performance shouldn't be an issue at all and viewing the game is easy.
Ontop of that it holds a good engine so even when there's spam everywhere the game will run smoothly.
Reassembly also inspires creativity, even if you aren't creative and bad at making things look good, the game still  assists you, and if you can make good looking machines the game makes them look even better out of the editor.
Gameplay is something not many use but regardless even if you get 5+ capitol mega ships you will still find something which will scare you and hunt you down followed by killing you.
However the best part by far in my opinion is the fact what you make, is whatever ships you make and add to your fleet design, will be randomly spawning and recreated which always gets me hyped when I see my own creations in use.

Generally i'd give this game a 10/10
Graphics - 10/10, Simplistic and easy to understand
Sound/Music - 10/10, Clear and easy to understand along with always being interesting
Gameplay - 10/10 Allows creativity and is in good balance

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first saw this game I was overjoyed. I bought it, even though $30 is quite a steep price for a game of this size, but for the most part it was worth it. Ever since I bought it the Dev has been active in updating the game and has made some major improvements on the ai and visuals as a whole. I think one of the latest updates that gave the ships and stations a glow based on their color added even more to the game's beauty. I love the idea of being able to design my own ships and take over the galaxy. Not to mention getting to see other people's creations (and getting to blow them to ****ing pieces).

But this game does start to get old after a certain point. At the moment there are 7 factions, and I've been able to get to the endgame of just about each one of them, but after you do that.... there's nothing really to do. You conquer one galaxy, move on to the next, and do the same exact thing, and the hardest ships sadly are always the same, (the blue and pinkish purple ones) which are located in the middle, which sadly never changes. Faction balancing is also a problem right now. The red faction atm is completly useless and almost impossible to get anywhere. The blocks it has are far weaker than any other faction (other than its weapons, which do pack a punch) and its ships get completely destroyed almost instantly when you're in the starting stage with the faction. Even when you start creating bigger ships with them they get crushed by other factions who have far better blocks. That brings me to my next point, the lack of options when it comes to blocks for some factions. For example, a faction like the green race (the 2nd option in the menu) has 47 different blocks, whereas some of the others will only have a little over 20 (and are very limited when it comes to weapon variance).

Another thing that should have been in this game but is not is multiplayer. Sure there's going to be tournaments where you can pit your ships against other ships, but only with the ai using your ship instead of you... If I created a ship to my liking, I want to use that ship to my liking in a pvp environment. Sadly the Dev said that this is probably not going to happen beacuse he'd have to take the game apart to implement a multiplayer function. So if you're going into this game thinking that that's going to be an option. It's most likely not going to happen.

Overall, this game is very fun and I would definatley reccomend buying it, but wait until after it comes out this coming thursday (the 19th) because it's going to be going down to $15 I believe. The creativity in this game is nearly endless, and many good times can be had, but unfortunetly you won't beable to do this with friends in the same galaxy and once you do conquer that galaxy, it's going to get repetetive.

I'd give it an 8/10. Pick it up and enjoy it if you want a creative experience in the sci-fi world.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game may not look like much. Heck, there aren't even any textures, but i must say, Reassembly has quickly become one of my favorite steam games of all time.

The main focus of the game is collecting resources from space plants (which seem to grow on anything that isn't constantly flying at full speed) and ships that belong to enemy factions. These resources can then be sold to friendly stations, who will not only give you credits, but also use the collected resources to build friendly ships, who in turn also collect resources to continue the cycle. Other than the initial ships in the world when you start the game, every ship, turret, and station must be spawned in from a factory (which is attached to another ship, turret, or station) when said factory has enough resources to build. All ships, plants, and debris are persistantly exsistant in the world, even when you leave the area. I cannot express in words how tantalizing the very idea of such a vast yet simple cycle is. Fortunantly, I CAN say (and with absolute certainty) that you MUST buy this game!

PS: The dev team is actually active, so don't be scared of the early access" label.

reviewText:
This. Beautiful. Game.
For those who enjoy having the ability to build literally almost EVERYTHING for yourself, this is very, very, very welcoming to the creative minds out there. Every single aspect of the ship is COMPLETELY up to you, as you build your ship (and soon) fleet; not just build, but evolve.

At first, you might get lost real easily by how the game starts out, dropping you in the middle of the game, letting you get your hands in the thick of it with no real instruction. EXPERIMENT! This game is literally endless, with no real, true penalties to stop you from doing whatever you want. From a few simple polygons, you clump it together slowly, piece by piece, and learn what YOU enjoy, and find to work, and improve off it. Not only that, but this game can conform to the way you wish to play easily, so there is NEVER any one, right way to play.

Wish to go in hard and heavy, with a giant, bulk-head cruiser? Go ahead, and charge at enemies with a hailstorm of laser beams. Or stay it safe, and strafe your enemies and snipe from afar with powerful missles and energy shots to obliterate the enemy. It is entirely put into the hand of the creator: You.

I bought this when it was at $30; I would do it again and again. I found it good enough to actually post a review for the FIRST TIME. With a lovely $15 price tag, and with how well sewed this whole game is, based on such a simple concept and turned into something limitless, I could nearly argue it's the best game I've ever played in my life thus far.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
“It’s like watching Battlestar Galactica through a kaleidoscope!”

This is one of my favorite 2D games at the moment and WHY I SAY THAT YOU MAY ASK? Let me start with the basics: Reassembly is an action oriented spaceship building game. Created by Anisoptera Games, an independent studio based in Los Angeles. Mainly inspirited in Lego and insect behavior in a world where everything is modular.

Reassembly

You start to build your very own ship piece by piece (ships are assigned a specific value based on their size) and most of the factions will cap out at 8,000P. Obviously it will take some time to get there ;). There are 7 factions in this universe and all of them play and work differently (insectoid, angley, squarish, plantlike or cristal like are some examples). One faction prioritizes high damage while other will get armor mostly. All of them have specific tactics and this will impact in their weapon choices.

You can also unlock most of the factions by killing large and valuable ships aligned to them. Once you destroy an specific amount (or, in other words, you make that faction lose an specific amount of value), you unlock that faction to play with.

Combat

Wield a wide variety of projectile and beam weapons, missiles, rockets and torpedoes, drones, and more against your enemies. Defend yourself with shields, armor, point defense systems, and pure maneuverability. The combat is a mix of skill, tactics, and preparation – an expertly piloted fighter can take down an enemy fleet, but having a well balanced arsenal helps. I can’t explain this better.

Art & environment

Maps are beautiful and the music flows with it. Procedural generated open living worlds where each faction fight for survival and evolution travelling though wormholes. There are usually a lot of “agents” (player fleets) spawning in the universe defending the sectors and spaceships, in Command mode you can pay them to join your fleet and seek you places to emerge. You need to conquer specifics zones to make spaceships emerge or grow your bases. But be careful, the big enemy fleet is looking these places to destroy them. Scavenge for resources, investigate disturbances, self repair, reproduce and take your fleet to the next stage.

Reassembly Reassembly
Reassembly Reassembly
Reassembly
Artificial Intelligence

AI is incredible. When you have a decent fleet of spaceships including your mother♥♥♥♥ing leadership… YOU WILL DIE… A LOT. AI ships can retreat if overwhelmed because they know how to measure the incoming attack. You need to plan how to attack and how to approach the battle and maybe take advantage of impromptu battles between rival factions to recover objectives, or run away after your opponent calls in reinforcements. In screen there can be around 150 ships in crossfire (it will run smoothly and at a decent framerate if you have nice hardware, otherwise you will be laggy).

You can only target 1 enemy at time with you entire fleet and that is a questionable design choice. A small system to target different ships would be nice in Command mode. The overall gameplay is very nice. Sometimes maneuvering big ships can be frustrating in places with a high amount of ships and planets, but is not that bad. We have three control types: Keyboard Only, Mouse and Keyboard, and Gamepad. This is very nice and completely user configurable, from colors to buttons, keys, even control schemes.

And well, we can’t have it all… No true multiplayer mode(can’t fight other players in real-time) the AI takes over other people’s ship designs and places them in your worlds. Obviously, you need to upload your fleet when you go through a wormhole. Last time a tried that Steam completely crashed, so some additional work towards multiplayer would be appreciated. PLEASE LET US PLAY IN REAL-TIME.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Unsustainable game.

While certainly a gem above a mountain of garbage games released by the truckload, the way this game is structured is going to kill itself, due to lack of meaning and arbitrary limitations.

You will have satisfaction from the mechanics of building, flying and shooting ships, but those will be cut short by having to grind for points to actually build anything remarkable and combat will be outright impossible when your weapons deal less damage than how fast the enemy shields can regenerate, forcing you to grind before the game actually becomes viable to play. And when you do finish grinding, there is no challenge or meaning left to play.

Wasted potential, but worth a few hours.
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Seriously an amazing game if you're looking for something to stretch your creative muscles.  You choose one of many playable factions, each unique in the parts and weapons available to them.  Using said parts, you create a 2D spaceship and begin to pioneer your faction to victory.

Things to note:
-This game has no story.  It is purely driven by you making a story yourself, or simply wanting to conquer the generated world.

-All movement in the game is physics based, and your ships are only as good as you build them.  This means there is something similar to a puzzle/strategy aspect of the game when building your ships.  If this is unappealing, I would be hesitant to recommend this game to you.
A possible solution to this problem is the implementation of the Steam Workshop.  This allows people to upload entire factions/fleets for you to use, but in my opinion you are mission out on half if not more of the game if you aren't building things.

-Replay value is arguable, and very dependant on the player.  If you are someone who likes experimenting with strategies, or challenging yourself by say, limiting your options by a personal rule, then you will most likely find it easy to sink hours into Reassembly.

In closing, I will simply say that Reassembly is a very rewarding game for those who enjoy top-down shooters, side scrollers, and creating functional and even beautiful things.  If you find it difficult to find personal motivation with a game, maybe double check other games on your wishlist before buying.

P.S. If you're into systematically destroying A.I. populations, this game could be for you.

reviewText:

If you don't like sci-fi and disliked art class when you were young, there is a fair chance you won't get much traction with this game, but if you are creative, imaginative, and love sci-fi, this game is a splendid creativity tool.

In the end a Review is about one thing, is the game fun, and for me, and likely for those others who enjoy science-fiction and creativity tools, this game is definitely fun, prepare to sink hours into tweaking the designs for your fighters, capital ships, and stations.

reviewText:
First part is only for in-depth explanation, also may contain SPOILERS:

Scroll past for basics

I have been playing this game a lot recently, and I love it.  I'm usually a little worried when I look at an alpha stage game because I have a few that I have bought in the past and never play, not because it was necessarily a bad game, or that the devs were bad, but because I have a very short attention span, and a lot of games.  The games that I tend to focus on are ones like reassembly, because you can take it as seriously as you want and the gameplay is ongoing, as in, you can go through wormholes and either upload the fleet you have currently in your saved ship designs chart, or you can actually 'go through' the wormhole and end up in an entirely different universe.  This is actually the part that I like most about the game, the first time I ran into a wormhole I decided to see what it did, after I went through my computer crashed and it deleted my whole save, which made me kinda sad, mainly because I thought my fleet just leaft me wouldn't come back, but ever since it has worked great.

Other than it crashing that one time, this game is spectacular, you are provided with 8 factions to play as(I think there are 8 playable one's anyway), and each faction has loads of powerful weapons and methods of defense.  The game makes it feel as though you are actually the commander of a whole race(being able to change the production of any factory weilding ship or station), and a power limit that allows you to construct massive ships bristling with weaponry.  The graphics are 2D, but that seriously doesn't matter, the visual effects are stunning, and the sound effects are also top-notch.  The ship crafting system is just like they promise, you can build anything you want, given you have ingenuity and know how shapes work.  The soundtrack is surprisingly good for galactic domination, and has a very spacy, electronicy feel.  The A.I. is pretty smart, not human smart, but it will use it's advantages against you, especially agent ships, cuz remember, they could be made by me, or you, or anybody.  With all that other stuff in mind, I have a pretty nice computer and a really old and outdated monitor, so i run most games on ultra, except crysis, or that type of stuff.  Most of the time this game runs fine, but if i have a big fleet, and im fighting a huge battle with hundreds of ships, it gets quite laggy until everything is dead.

The basic facts are as follows:
Pros:
- Gameplay is fast paced and fun
- Makes you feel like the king of a space empire
- Ship-building system is perfect
- Graphics yo
- Sounds great
- Agents add tremendous difficulty
- it's quality ♥♥♥♥, buy it

Cons:
- Large fleet battles can cause lag
- crashes are few and far between, but excpected, cuz beta

reviewText:
Design magnificient 2D space ships in a great and efficient editor that's better than most of vector graphic editors I've used. Your civilization is using the ships you've designed so you can see the progress throughout the galaxy as you iteratively upgrade your ships to be bigger, better, faster, stronger and annihilate all opposition in an extremely satisfying way.

Thanks to wormohles (author calls it async multiplayer), you wage war against other players' creatinos and send your warships into other people's universes to do the same! This is a fantastic way to deliver user generated content directly in the game without hassle and reward you for contributing - sending your creations to wreak havoc in parallel universes. How cool is that?!

I love space games, especially 2D ones like Space Pirates And Zombies and I also love engineering games where I build vehicles myself for efficiency (Robocraft, From the Depths, Space Engineers) and this game brings so much to the table I sit here with my mind blown.

Did I menion one of the 7 playable races is using bloody penrose tiles? What the... just wow!

I think there is space for more user content awesomeness like player designed races (from the tiles already available) that would increase the already huge replay value to unseen levels, but you could call that a greed as the game is great already as is. And imagine downloading new races (tile sets) from workshop... yeah, greed... hmm...

This is a very special game and I deeply thank the dev for creating this masterpiece!

Few highlights:
* ships are damaged piece by piece
* ships reassemble themselves piece by piece
* ships with factories can spawn other ships (with factories...)
* maneuverability is decided by the placement of engines (finally)
* 7 playable races are unique and many strategies and designs are available
* you can test your ships against other ships and even against each other across save files
* galaxy feels alive, almost like Spore
* user generated content integrated into game with 0 effort to both consume and create (just fly through wormhole and even get reward, yay)

I bought this at full price and I regret nothing. I can't say that about many Steam purchases I did :-p

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me just begin by saying this game is in early developement and it may have its bugs but still is worth playing through. the gameplay and concept are a jewel among other games. there are strategy and shooter elements along with casual elements that make this game just an all around excellent experience both for hardcore action players and more relaxed casual players.
The ability to make your own ship one block at a time and perfect it and then see other stations and ships spawn your design is a beautiful site. This is an excellent marriage of strategy and shooter along with a wonderful atmospheric environment. the price for this game may seem a little high but I personally think it is well worth the price for the experience you can have in the game.

pros
- modular ship building

- unique playable factions each specializing in a particular playstyle.
- interesting encounters with other players ship designs.
- early access
- inifinite ways to play
cons
- early access
- lack of uniqueness with some factions
- weak factions
- lacking content

reviewText:
Game is great. Though a little scarce on parts at the moment, I hope they are planning on adding more parts and weapons. You can make just about anything in this game from tiny scout fighters to giant dreadnaughts and space stations. Installed it and played it trying to keep making the better ship only to lose track of time 4 hours later. This is a great time killer. Graphics are unique, gameplay is solid, though can be repetitive at times with gathering resources.

I do hope they plan on adding ship sharing perhaps via steam workshop. Currently the only wait to see other peoples ships are to hunt down “agents” which are usually player made ships most of the time. I’m still grasping the game within the first 4 hours if me losing track of time.  Hopefully in the future, we have the ability of a more diverse fleet command system, and more parts. All in all, great game for $15 full price.

EDIT: I should note that after putting more time into the game, I have found that you can download player fleets by just going to the Reassembly Homepage and looking at the sync list. Its as easy as just downloading and importing fleets. Check it out: http://www.anisopteragames.com/sync/latest.html

On another note, I only played as the first faction. Upon unlocking more factions, you have unique parts and weapons used by that faction. So there is quite a variety with the 6 or 7 different factions available right now. Definitely hard to break away from this, as I'm constantly facing player made fleets and always trying to enhance my fleet to defeat that fleet. I was constantly defeated by one fleet for about an hour before finally upgrading and fine tuning my weapons to defeat them. Simply one of the best arcade style games I've played in a long time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reassembly is a game where you start out with a little ship and use various blocks and weapons to upgrade it. Eventually add a factory to it so you manufacture ships, maybe even give them factories so they can make more...
Put simply, there's a million different things to do. There's a reason this game doesn't have a single bad review - There's next to no complaints. The only thing I could comment on is what I think could be added, but it's all minor stuff like multiplayer.
The style is amazing. Using just vectors and particle physics the game is beautiful and doesn't need textures. It's appealing to the eye and good on those older computers.
The gameplay mirrors this. It's imple WASD to move, mouse to look, and mouse buttons to shoot. However weapon variants are high. Some are turret types that follow your mouse, some are fixed. You've got everything from plasma weaponry (Moderate range and moderate damage) to the feared Antimatter cannon (Moderate range EXTREMELY high damage.)
If you've ever wanted a game that actually brings something new to the creative sandbox" genre
date: this game is for you. The price is a little steep but in my opinion this is one of the few Early Access games that deserves the $30. You won't regret it."

reviewText:
TL;DR: Amazing unscripted top-down space combat/expansion indie game with great community and plethora of quality mods to add content to game. If you liked SPAZ or Starsector, you’ll LOVE this game!

For a game made by one guy, heck, even compared to other indie games with teams of developers, Reassembly ranks up with there with my favorites. Reassembly can be compared to Space Pirates and Zombies and Starsector, 2 other top-down space exploration/combat games; however, Reassembly has them both beat in customizability, unscripted expansion/development of the player faction, and ambience. The gameplay is easy to get into and gets as complex as your creativity can make it, yet still retains simplicity which makes it easy and fun to sit there creating a large complex spaceship tailored to your desires. As you expand and grow your faction, your AI will begin building ships you design for them and in order to expand more you could employ many ways to take over sectors of the galaxy. From bringing a fleet of ships to having a carrier with masses of drones or even piloting a singular dreadnought to carve through enemy territory, or even coming up with your own tactics as you can create any kind of ship you want block by block (even copy pasting big chunks of ships to create modular designs) the designs are limitless!

As for quantity of content, the base factions are interesting but when they get bland the developer made Reassembly open source allowing anyone to easily create their own factions or even universe altering mods and upload them for anyone to download and play from the Steam Workshop. The community, while small, is one of the nicest and most dedicated I’ve seen, and you’ll definitely never run out of quality new factions to download and try out or play against. This includes mods that change the entire galaxy to a star wars themed galactic war to mods that create a 2 faction war between humans and zombies in space, to... well just check the Workshop and you’ll see all the amazing stuff going on!

reviewText:
TL;DR Reassembly is a game that won't let you go even after dozens of hours, keeping you busy building your own Death Star and then sending a fleet of those to ruin someone's day.

The Spacetacular Spaceventure.
Reassembly is all about space and freedom of it. There are seven factions available, each with their own unique playstyle. You can peacefully grow plants and extract energy from solar panels, or you can set up your own fleet of doom and plunder the galaxy. You can take things down with precise lasers, continuous beams, play a pew-pew-em-up with plasma cannons and if that doesn't help - spam them with missiles until they die. For those who desire exotic methods of space annihilation, make your own sawblade of death. Choices are limitless.

Right in from the childhood.
There are just three resources in this game: R(esource), C(urrency) and P(ower), each made to limit or unbind your possibilities. The cycle seems to be simple - R is traded for C, C is spent on P, and P is how many hardware you can put into your ship to earn yourself more R. But it's harder than it sounds. You don't just buy hulls, glue cannons on them and go gunning things down. You build your own ship piece by piece, and that's where LEGO nostalgia hits. Space, energy and Power efficiency is what makes it hard and beautiful. You can put tons of armor and guns on your ship, but thrusters just won't carry such mass. You can be tanky and quick, but with little to no offense available. You can put powerful guns and quickly execute hit-and-run tactics, but two shots will annihilate your little scrap piece of death.

Spiky plants.
You'll find out soon enough.

Dark spirit fleet has invaded.
So, you've made your bulky space cannon of extreme vengeful execution of space heretics and conquered the whole galaxy. And that's it? No, of course not. There are wormholes and agents.

Wormholes is what gives Reassembly infiniteness. When you approach a wormhole you're offered to either pass through to a newly generated galaxy, or to send your current fleet to other worlds in form of agents.

Agents are what slows you down. They are well-equipped fleets made by other players, and they are extremely hard to defeat. There are usually 6-8 fleets on the galaxy map, and they're moving towards you. Slowly. But when they reach you, they start plundering your stations and ships. Until they are defeated, they'll find you and destroy you. But the reward for killing them is worth the trouble.

Boooooring!
Well then, recently there had been added Steam Workshop support. Test out all the new player ships and factions, unleash their power on others or get wrecked by their overpoweredness. I'd say that the choice is yours, but you don't really have any choice. The galaxy's cruel.

Conclusion
The best singleplayer experience I had in a while. For how much this game already has, I give it 10/10. For me, this is the indie Game of the Year.

reviewText:
Summary: Very fun game where you can let your creativity run free for hours at a time or in short bursts in breaks. Excellent modding capabilities.

Just because Reassembly lacks a third dimension, it doesn't skimp on content. Design your own ships to wage war on the rest of a barren voidspace filled with factions wanting to ruin your day.

Vast variety of gameplay styles, from the passive Farmers to the rush-them-first-and-ask-later Bees.

You can also pit your creations against others, or even your Steam friends', using tournament mode.

'Agent' fleets you fight are actually from other players after uploading them through wormholes.

Massive modding options from a good community. Choices range from hardcore mode factions to easy overpowered ones. Various quality of life mods too.

Would recommend to anyone who enjoys: Space Engineers, From the Depths, Kerbal Space Program.

reviewText:
Reassembly feels half-finished, and in the long run it's really disappointing. Yes, designing the ships is fun, and testing them is fun, and the big battles are fun. However, the fun runs out quickly and there are UI issues which pretty much kill any real possibility of sinking a significant amount of time into the game due to the repetition and frustration involved.

The User Interface has a very Early Access" feel to it. At one point after purchasing I came back to the Steam store page expecting to see an Early Access tag that I had overlooked.

At first
date: UI clunkiness seemed like a small problem. I liked the game. I was having fun gathering resources

voteText: and my ships were large enough to use it. At this phase of the game you think "Cool

It would be so much better if you could configure the way your factory makes ships. Here's how it works:  you move up to 4 ship designs into boxes at the top of the fleet screen. These designs will be built by your ship's factory when you press 'F' in-game.

The issue is that pressing 'F' builds the first ship in the queue

This will happen even with small ships that are the most maneuverable craft in the game. Yes
column36: your fleet that you saved up resources to build can easily get left behind on a high speed trip because they are truly terrible at avoiding stationary objects.\n\nAlso
column37: ships get stuck together all the time while they are "rebuilding" themselves after taking damage
column38: or right after they spawn from your factory on your main ship. It's laughable
column39:
as the two ships are merged and the AI ship is using all of its thrusters trying to go somewhere making it impossible to go where you are trying to go.

So all-in-all this feels like a half-finished Early Access title with potential. Unfortunately it's a finished game.

Summary: Game feels half-completed. Good ship designing
column42: nothing rewarding to do after unlocking all the parts and build points."

reviewText:
Built a spaceship that has two giant dragon heads with flames coming out and lasers for eyes.

11/10 would shoot lasers out of my dragon eyes again.

Silliness aside, I play a lot of computer games and love this one.  I rarely write reviews, that's how much I enjoy this game.  So let me help you decide since you're still reading because you're too lazy to watch a video clip of it on youtube (j/k, i read reviews of games before I buy too).  Do you like:
- sci fi games?  (Starcraft, EVE Online, Alpha Centauri)
- building characters in RPGs, building empires in 4X games, or creating custom units?  (think Armored Core, Alpha Centauri's unit editor, etc.)
- 2D arcade shooters, or people who like shooting things in general?

This game has elements of all of those.  Has a fun difficulty to it too, learning the mechanics, and being caught offguard by something new because you fight other people's spaceships in space sometimes, lol.  Testing your shapceships in automated AI duels against other player's spaceships is entertaining too, like watching a tournament in eSports.  Very entertaining game, excellent graphics, awesome soundtrack.  Music is the kind of rare video game music that you can listen to for hours and still enjoy.  The music reminds me of the PC game Shatter" soundtrack - a game which I've never played before but love the music of (look up Shatter OST on youtube).  Highly recommend Reassembly.  So wow."

reviewText:
This is a simple sandboxxy space combat game.  Focus is on design and some very arcade style combat.

NOTE: I haven't played past the first 'race' - and the playstyle of other races are different - but in a limited sense.

In theory you could do economy building, but you only control one ship (effectively) so actually building a economy to produce masses of ships appears a distant dream.

Complaints about the balance are justified.  Ships designed by other players will inhabit your world, and they run the gammut from harmless to ... very challenging.

I'm continuously annoyed by 3 things.

1 - Economic development is unmanageable, and resource farms are often eradicated by combat.  It's not merely a re-seed problem - you can actually destroy asteroids - the 'ground' on which you plant farms.  Only one faction can effectively generate farms. Humans can push asteroids around and then hope that seeds spawn before the plants / asteroids are destroyed by combat.

2 - The blocks aren't standardized.  The slight differences in size and connection point locations are amazingly frustrating.  75% of my ship design time is spent trying to find a way of connecting blocks that are off by a few pixels.
As a bonus sometimes the order in which you assemble the exact same shape can allow or disallow a connection.

3 - Progression is very shallow.  You can spend your 'money' on:
- new weapons / modules (but nothing outside your faction and there is no 'tree' or research time, just a list of items and prices).
- AI ships (like one of your faction's ships?, you could make one or just buy it)
- Size limit increases.

'Size limit' is the only thing that prevents you from making collossal ships at the start.  Modules and Weapons (but not hull) have a complexity cost, and your complexity limit starts at 300.  You simply spend 'money' to buy a larger limit, and 2000 appears to be a good target for a good combat design.

You also have resources which are used to produce new ships.  You can trade resources for 'money' by dropping them off at a station (I haven't discovered any enemy stations).
