reviewText:
I see the appeal of this game, but once a-freaking-gain, it's a title that shipped long before it was finished.

I LOVE these types of games. Build ship, gather resources, build bigger ship, smash enemies. That part of this game is fun. However, it's a broken PoS. Half the things don't work properly.

List of broken stuff:
-Drones fly off without reason into space and die.
-Missle targeting flys around in circles for no reason.
-Auto-target turrets don't auto-target 75% of the time. They sit there idling.
-Auto-fire doesn't auto-fire when enemies are nearby 75% of the time. They sit there idling (noticing a pattern here?).
-Ship re-building randomly doesn't work. Once, I was half-dead, went to allied territory and went to take a leak. Then I made a sandwich. Came back 5 minutes later and I still wasn't rebuilt. I had to exit and re-enter the game.
-Sheilds randomly malfunction . No, there was not an EMP, the sheilds simply didn't want to turn on so I had to go kill myself to get them to work again (even though dying in this game isn't much of a consequence, it's still annoying!).
-Thrusters on the side of the ship do jack-all. No matter what angle I put them at, strafing is a hundred times slower than going backward and forward. I put LITERALLY 10 times more thrusters on the sides of the ship than on the back of the ship, and no change. Barely any strafing at all. A thruster on the side of the ship does 1/100th the power of a thruster on the back/forward of the ship simply for the fact that it's on the side. I'm not sure if this is a glitch or if it's designed to be like that, either way, it's really damn annoying.
-Half the time, the ship I'm currently flying either wants to go forward, or turn. Never both at the same time, but one or the other, exclusively.
-Entering or exiting a menu resets the volume of the music to MAXIMUM. I play with my speakers pretty high up and turn most of the in-game volume down. This usually isn't a problem except in this game. Every time I go into the menu to change my ship, my fleet's ships, check the map, or pause the game, the volume for the music cranks all the way up to 100% for about a second, deafening me. This is more of a personal problem, but it's just another glitch that shows the game released too soon.
-Every third game, my base spawns in the middle of god damned no where. No enemies within a hundred miles. Just dead, deep space between me and them. At the beginning of the game, you're especially weak, so you rely on your allies to help significantly, but it's impossible in these games, so the best advice I have is to just remake it. Another annoyance.
-Every few minutes more I play this game I find another glitch/bug/thing I don't like.

Positives:
-Music is awesome. It gets my blood pumping at times and at others it makes me sit back and relax to the joys of the graphics.
-Looks awesome. The graphics of this game are amazing. Beautifully done.
-Ship building is simple, yet deceptively complex. You can't simply stick a massive shield on one side of the ship and have it work properly. You need to counter-balance it with another shield, or something with similar mass. Center of gravity of the ship actually matters and you can easily build a ship by accident that can only fly in circles. I love that!
-Individual part destruction. When a part gets hit, you lose it, simple as that. If you lose your left aft engines, then guess what, you're flying in circles 'till it regenerates buddy.
-Individual part regeneration. After a short period (dependant on the part), it regenerates, free of cost, without having to go back to a station to repair and refuel.
-Unlock a part and you can use it as many times as you like.
-Free ship re-design. Re-design your ship over and over and over aaaaaand oooooooveeeeeeer again all you want, it's free. You're gonna need those remakes to create a good one. You don't even have to enter a spaceport and whatnot.

Once again, I'd love to love this game, I really would. There's a lot of great features and design aspects of the game I really love, but it's just not finished. It's just yet another game released before its time.

reviewText:
Additctive fun, but don't forget to set your alarms since you'll lose track of time!

With a screen full of particle effects the game runs smoothly.

You can design any 2D shape you can think of given the limitation of the pieces per faction. Practically any design is possible with enough pieces.

Ship design is done by you.  You shape it's toughness, layout, engine placement, maneuverability, weaponry, and other things related to each faction.

There isn't much direction, but the game is simple, shoot everyone else.  There is a simple tutorial to get you to realize some things that might not be apparent.

Some achievements are weak, but others actually take time and effort.

Other player's ships show up in your universe to battle against.

reviewText:
I've always been a sucker for customization and Reassembly offers the second best ship-building experience that I have ever had. I think that I spent more time perfecting and refining my ship designs than I did fighting. Seven playable factions each with their own unique weapons and playstyles. Depending on your combat preference, some factions are easier to play than others. You kill things, buy new components and increase the point limit for your ships. I consider a faction finished when you've bought all upgrades and built an 8000 point Superdreadnaught that is pretty much unstoppable.

I bought this game during a sale but after playing it I can say that, for me at least, I would have been happy to pay full price.

The only things that I would change in this game would be an option to disable tutorials when you start a new faction and perhaps a few more components for some of the factions that only have two different types of weapons.

reviewText: Reassembly...a game where you can build you very own fleet piece by piece. They made the building system rather intuitive, but it is a bit difficult to master.  I did enjoy when I had my fleet and I was just cutting a warpath through my first world until I got to the wormhole and sent my fleet to other worlds and logged off for the night. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I feel beta has been out long enough to write this. I was part of alpha since the summer, and ever since my first glance at the game I was in love. Polygons with partical effects moving polygon clumps that fire polygons with effects at other polygons? What not to love! Although the graphical style is symplistic, it keeps amazing me how complex a ship that's essentially shifting shades of  two colours can look. Gameplay? Great. Although at times I dearly wish there was a way to choose your spawn point so you don't get almost trapped at a station over and over again because enemies keep attacking you as you spawn, it's for the most part rediculously fun trying to continually improve your ship to take down enemies while at the same time making a fleet that's not too shabby for fighting.

What do I Give this? Solid 8/10. It could do better in some respects, so it's not worthy of a nine, and in my opinion no game is ever worth a ten since there are faults in every game, but for the most part I'm in love. I highly recommend this game and I also believe that the thirty dollars will be worth it to help with the development and likely get your ideas implemented, as well as getting to see the game evolve into it's final state like I and many others have been doing for a long time.

reviewText:
Reassembly is a space combat game, in which you build your own ship, and can also design all the ships your faction spawns.

The ultimate goal is to conquer the galaxy, eliminating all other factions (I've never managed).

It's got a great atmosphere, the galaxy really feels alive, with plants shooting their spores from one asteroid to another, all the different factions doing their business, battles raging, quiet stretches of space littered with the remains of destroyed ships, asteroid fields and wormholes.

It also has a sandbox mode (with command line and all), and a tournament mode, where you can organize battling championships.

All in all, it's a great game! As you can see (or not, depending on when you are reading the review), I sank over 92 hours into this game in two weeks. That's quite a lot - and for good reason, it's super addictive. It felt quick because I sank so many hours into it in a short time, I think, but it's got great replayability, I still play it occasionally.

Slightly dissapointed with some unlockable factions, and the UI isn't great (no way to save individual ship weapon bindings?), but I don't regret buying the game at all, it was (and still is, to be honest) a blast.

[EDIT (Feb 2016)] - Binding issue seems to be fixed! Devs are still fixing bugs and facilitating modding! :D

Most people should be comfortable with full price, it's not an expensive game at all.

Go ahead and buy it! :D

reviewText:
I'm not sure if I should hate this game for having such a floaty and, to newcomers, hard to operate flight controls.
I'm not sure if I should love this game for being so creative, offering an unlimited amount of customization options for me to shove onto my shop and make it look like a blatant ripoff of a Star Destroyer, while having rewarding combat, a pretty cool RTS kinda gameplay where you can build and create your own army to throw at enemies or other players, and so many different ways to play, whether I want to ram my ship into an enemy ship with a tiny little interceptor with a photon sword, or just show up with a massive supercruiser with guns coming out of every orifice.

I'll give it a thumbs up to show you which option I went with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a bit like SPaZ with total ship customization. Completing objectives like capturing points and killing enemies awards you with upgrade points that you can use to buy more weapons and systems for your ships. You can start from the ground up to customize your ship, which gives you the freedom to make a spectacularly crappy ship or the ship of awesome, all governed by how many upgrade points you put into ship total size. It's so fun, and I constantly go back and tweak ships when I unlock new techs.

The price is higher than an indie game, and that's a bit of a negative, but there is plenty of value in the ship customization. There are different ship races to unlock, so there is a bit of replay value. The ship races differ dramatically, so it feels different evey time you start fresh with a new race.

Creativity in ship building is the shining point of this game, and I'm glad I bought it.

This game is fun and functional in its early access state, so don't worry about buying something buggy and unfinished. It's good!

reviewText:
Reassembly is a decent sandbox shooter that has a relaxed atmosphere.  The best part, obviously, is building your own ships and experimenting with designs.  As you gather resources you can purchase better parts.  Each of the factions have a unique theme and require different strategies to design. The ship building interface is very intuitive and easy to use, which is a big plus.

It's a nice, chill single player game but I think overall it lacks depth, which I will describe below.
There's really no need for specialization against any particular foe. With such flexibility in ship design I was hoping this game could push this concept more.  Once you have a decent ship it works against all factions almost universally. You can fiddle with designs for a while, but in the end, more expensive parts will make you better.  With many factions it's quickest to destroy enemy ships for resources, so that becomes your sole focus.  Once you max out your ship, basically nothing stands in your way.  Unless you tried to get all the Steam achievements, like I did, there's not much of an end game to keep you playing.  I spent most of my time on this game grinding out achievements.

In conclusion, it was fun but lack of depth put me on the fence on this one.  After getting all of the achievements, I feel like I tapped out all of my reasons to keep playing.   I would have liked to see the ship building aspect developed further.  I'm leaning on the fence to recommend this game, but it was still fun for the time being.   If you feel like this game might be something you'll be interested in then you'll probably enjoy it.

reviewText:
Honestly, this is my first review. I have to say, I really like this game. There are somethings that could be done, like more content.There is just a lot of things in certian faction where as others, they're really empty. I spent my first session on this game, and completed it within 12hours(hit the cap and conqured the map (once) and got allraces). That's one sitting. (on weekend) I really wish some more things were added to it, mods filled the rest but it's just grinding and doing the same things over again. I built a fleet to the size of 700+ ships. NOTHING STANDS IN YOUR WAY. I'm talking cheap small ships though, like 42-45p. The 8000P Cap is dis-tasteful. Although I got a mod to increase the maxium amount of P. It feels dead. There is nothing striving me forward. Usually, when I play games were you reach an extent of 'stability' in a game, I would decide to expand and make things more efficient, bigger, better than they're suppose to be in the first place. (like an ever growing population) This game is diffrent. You have to Build a ship, and get stations, and farm resources. That aside, I really loved this game with building, customizing, there is alot of freedom to it that I enjoy. One things I found a very easy way to exploit was to just put all my weapons on Point Defense. No need for me too actually use my guns myself. Another thing I hated was the weapons, there wasn't any speacialization or limitations with what I could stick on my ship as long as it could fit with the P limitation it was fine. I am happy with the factions we have, I don't think neccesarily we need more. A storyline would be nice, I just go around shooting everything instead of expanding with friendlies, making alliances, trading, capital ships. I wish this game was a lot more than it is now. One more thing I like to add is the AI, the AI doesn't know how to do anything. All my weapons carve straight to their core after they decide to 'rush' me.


PROS:
*Great Community
*Great Mods
*Great custimization and build
*Great Potential


CONS:
*Lacks content and variation
*Limitation in P
*Challenging Enemies
*Once you hit endgame, nothing can touch you.
*AI Lacks


5.745/10

reviewText: Like building ships? Buy this game. Like hectic combat? Buy this game. Like leading fleets with very little control over your subordinates? Buy this game. Like minimalistic art style that still manages to be beautiful, where you can sit and watch the asteroid flowers grow for hours on end in a strange zen-like state? Buy this game.\n\n(I kickstarted this game, and am by far the most pleased with this product out of any other game I've invested" in)"

Reassembly is a game that is difficult to categorize. There are elements of building, space combat, and rts (in a somewhat abstract way). The game allows great creativity in shipbuilding style and combat philosphy.

I find this game to be great fun. You can start with a pre-built ship, or make your own right away. The game includes an AI driven tester that will pit your design against other designs so that you can tweak and perfect your ship before flying it. I prefer to fly around and earn some credits first for upgrades. The goal is simple - expand your territory, earn credits, use credits to upgrade the power level of ship you are permitted to fly, unlock upgrades and build better ships.

The game learns from how you play and from facing your ships. Eventually you will face ships made by other players. Also you will unlock other factions that you can play which have different ship components. The replay value is immense as no playthrough will ever be identical to another.

The graphics are clean and simple, not ultra-detailed, with nice effects, slightly retro and modern at the same time.  The game includes excellent controller support for in-game play, but for ship creation you have to use mouse and keyboard. I think controller support for the building phase of the game would probably be awkward and difficult to implement, so I don't blame the devs...

10/10 If there is something wrong with this game, I don't know what it is!

It took me about an hour to fall into this game but once I finally got the hang of it I was hooked.  Its not until you can start producing your own personal fleet of ships that this game really starts to shine.  The graphics are beautiful, however there are some slowdowns when the huge battles start.  I turned a few physics options down a bit and it was much better.  I felt like I took a bit of a chance buying this in early access but I feel like its well worth it.  I hope to see some more multiplayer options soon.  There is a lot to do already to keep you busy while the devs work on even more content as it sets now.
It's so hard to stop playing.
Awesome game super fun, only wish there was a website to post your ships and download other peoples

This is the kind of game I lose myself in.  2d open world, er, space war.  Straight forward without a story but you wont miss it, when it comes to building the perfect ship there is a lot of depth to be had.  A must have for SPAZ fans.

This game is awesome.  Ever played a game and wished you could tweak your ship?  Well now you can.
Any type of ship imaginable is buildable: Carriers that launch leigons of drone fighters; Battleships with heavy cannons and a myriad of point defense lasers; Missile Cruisers with racks upon racks of guided missiles; Destroyers with cannons, lasers, beam weapons, and torpedo launchers; Fighters with rapid-fire plasma guns, lasers, and rockets.  Weapons can be bound to control groups and can be set to fire in grouped bursts or in a continuous chain.

The game starts you out with a well-made tutorial.  It provides guidance on learning the game and getting your fleet up and running (yes, you can build ships that can build more ships), without being intrusive or pushy.  All of this building requires competing for and collecting the resources that grow on nearby asteroids.  These raw resources can then be used to construct additional ships or exchanged at one of the friendly stations you've activated for credits to fund research and fleet upgrades.

The physics in this game are fantastic.  Fire a heavy cannon, and your ship recoils.  Hit something or blow something up, and chunks fly off and blow apart.  The field of wreckage that remains after an epic battle is part of what makes this game so satisfying.

The graphics are beautiful.  Colors and effects are vibrant. (Just go look at the screenshots!)

The music is suitable and soothing, but not particularly noteworthy, but the sound effects from firing weapons are right on point.

There are still a few bugs.  The game never seems to remember my control settings, and the game sometimes has trouble starting (restarting the launcher seems to work for the latter).

TLDR:  I don't usually write reviews, but this game is too awesome not to.  It is a definite must buy and well worth the price.

I figured this would be a game I'd play for 15 minutes here and there.  6 hours later I realized how much time had passed since I started playing.  If word of this game gets out, it's going to be a hit.

This game is beautiful. A physics-based WASD space shooter nestled in the most enjoyable sandbox builder I've ever played.

Pros    Your ship is constantly rebuilding itself - leading to great gameplay moments like sniping enemy cores, narrow escapes, on-the-fly hull redesign, etc...
Instead of being a solo ship, you are part of a faction. You gain acess to new tech and bigger ships by advancing your faction's power which does a great job of making you feel integrated into the game world.
Each faction is very diverse, with its own unique attributes and building elements. These constraints help shipbuilding to stay fresh and encourage experimentation.
Fantastic ship editor makes it fun and easy to make your designs real.
Good tutorial to get you started with the core mechanics.
Community content - at any time you can approach a wormhole and upload your fleet. These fleets can then spawn in other players' games. What makes this awesome is that you don't just encounter single ships from these fleets, but whole communities with multiple ship styles from the same user.
A sense of progression. I typically lose interest in sandbox builders where you have to collect resources to use in crafting. Reassembly uses point-based ship construction, so you don't have to collect resources to build your ship - just to expand your point cap. This gives you concrete goals to work towards over time, while again providing constraints to motivate continual re-design of your fleet.
Cons    You haven't purchased this game yet! Go support these developers!

A lot of hours in the last few days into this game.  Basically its a top down shooter that you build bits and pieces if your ship.

Its oddly satisfying to cut your opponents ship in half, through an asteroid.. ;)

I think there's a lot to offer in the game, though it could use a bit more content, maybe more/different pieces.  Multi player would be killer, even if it was a wild sandbox.
Having  a blast, great game.  10hrs so far and I've still got sooo much I want to try.

Great game, if you like building and improving spaceships and and simple gameplay, don't hesitate and get this game. There's enough variation in the spaceship building blocks and enemies to make you think. You've got to experiment with the various builds and styles of play to get a winning combination. Also, you can design and add ships to your own fleet, adding more strategic combinations of missiles, rays and drones. Great fun and will eat hours of your life.\nHighly recommended.

reviewText:
Sometimes, two children building spaceships out of LEGO will be in the same room and without adult supervision. They will probably start by dogfighting their plastic creations, but sooner or later they will be taking turns to throw each spaceship into the other. This is the game of those models.

Reassembly's ship creation is simple but pretty intricate in its outcome - you strap 2D weapons, components, inert hull pieces and engines to your command module until you're happy with the result. Ships can be any size, shape, scale (ships can be worth 50 points or 8000), tactical role and degree of effectiveness. You could build the Serenity, a Star Destroyer, a butterfly, a cartoon house with drone launchers in the windows, a space station shaped like Dover Castle or even a sniper rifle with a spinal death weapon for the barrel and a point defence laser for the trigger.

At any time during the customisation you can press the 'test' button, and the AI will fly the ship against available stock designs in a 1v1 arena battle. You can also use the tournament game mode to watch battles between selected designs from any of your save files, any of your friends' save files and any .lua files someone has shared elsewhere on the internet. The devs run occasional open tournaments for ship designs, as do some youtubers.

Single player is utterly devoid of story, it's basically a sandbox galaxy in which various mutually hostile factions hold territory. Kill things and provide R (the production resource) to your factory ships to gain C (research resource). Use C to increase your ship's build limit and unlock new components to play with, or to hire friendly ships to follow you around. Install a factory on your ship to be able to spend R on your custom escort ships, which you can release for more C. Conquer and comsume the galaxy, find a wormhole, travel to the next galaxy and start over. The visuals are pretty nice, the opposing factions are diverse and the fact that your escort ships are ones you yourself have designed makes the campaign feel more exclusive and personal in a 4X-ey sort fo way.

The 7 playable factions generally handle differently, which adds some replayability. Some factions have diamond or rhombus hull pieces, changing their look and design priorities. there's a faction with really cheap shield generators and sniper cannons that can spawn resource-generating space-plants, there's a faction with cheap high-damage weapons and deadly beam drones but very little effective armour, there's a faction whose only direct weapon is a spinal plasma launcher you build by stacking modular components on top of each other. There's one faction that gets nuke launchers and melee spikes.

On the downside though, some of the factions get their playstyle from a lack of versatlity and a poor choice of components. It's pretty demoralising to look at a new faction's full array of hardware and think 'is this it?' Tournaments can be dominated by Faction 4 (the modular plasma cannon one) and by 'spinny ships' (that exploit the AI's ability to lead targets, making them impossible to hit), the music is good but can be intrusive and gets repetitive after the first dozen hours or so. The campaign has almost no ships bigger than 3000P, meaning a player with the cap of 8000P gets to stomp everything with little effort or interesting events. They are small complaints but they do add up sometimes.

To finish, I'll say that Rassembly holds its players' attention not with a scripted or even emergent narrative, or with a great challenge, but with the promise of having something to tinker with. Working out the strengths of each weapon or design, using those extra 200P to give your flagship a little more punch, and reverse-engineering a design you saw on youtube that one time, are what contributes to an addictive and engaging experience that's well worth the £11 it asks for.

Early Access Review

Reassembly is an amazing game.  Similar to how Minecraft combined a 3D action sort of a game with gameplay that revolves around creativity using blocks and crafting, Reassembly does something similar in a sense. The combination of certain creative and radical mechanics with an existing game format makes for something much greater and more enjoyable in Reassembly.  The mechanics of the game when you are flying your spaceship remind me of asteroids, but the game is a lot deeper than that.  Reassembly is a top-down space shooter combined with a very open design mode where players create spaceships out of connectable pieces.  It also features reproducing spaceships :)

In the video posted here on Steam, the creator of the game mentions something about creating things of function and beauty.  In reassembly, both function and beauty are valuable end-goals for player creations.  No one likes an ugly ship.  However, since ships reproduce, it is important that the ships are viable.  If you want a ship to turn well and quickly, you have think out where to place the engines so that they rotate the ship.  If you want to protect the core, you may have to surround it with armor.  Design in the game becomes a very interesting process as the original concepts behind a design merge with the necessary requirements for survivability to generate successful ships, or perhaps I should say, successful offspring.

Early Access Review\n\nThis game is wonderful. It is the perfect combination of strategy with building, and action with fast-paced battles. It is not too hard, which is good. I find that some games go so far in depth, you get lost and give up. This game is the perfect ballance between easy and difficult.

Early Access Review

Early Access Review

I've never posted a review on Steam before, but Reassembly compelled me to do so.

Summary: This game is still in beta. It also has some of the most immersive aesthetics and mechanics of any game I've ever played. I have learned to approach it with the caution of a recovering drug addict in a pharmacy-- if I click the icon I can expect to lose at least several hours of my time, if not portions of my health, dreams, and/or general human function.

Criticisms: The only reasons I would hesitate to recommend it to my friends in its current state are 1) the effective lack of directed multiplayer, 2) the comparative ease once you start building capital ships, and 3) the lack of polish/balance across some of the playable factions.

1) I found in my playtime that some of what I enjoyed most in the game was the ship design testing process, where at any point you can place your design in the hands of an AI and have it fight best-of-three battles against up to five different AI controlled ships of similar power levels. I would love to have the ability to put my designs up against the designs of my friends and other players, whether one-on-one, faction vs faction, or in larger skirmishes or king of the hill matches.

2) Speaking of the king, once I completed a 8000P juggernaut and spent some time retooling my fleet even the center factions posed little threat (provided I didn't park in a plant faction death cluster or otherwise act a fool). As well, there was no longer any real use for the upgrade currency one you've maxed out the P limit and purchased all the weapon tiles. I haven't tried to achieve complete dominion of the entire game map yet, but the endgame isn't presently as enjoyable as the 20-30 hours I spent reaching it with the first faction (which is a pretty happy problem, granted).

3) As for the factions, the first one has tiles complete with descriptions giving you an idea of each tile's use, as well as some flavor text. The other factions (more recently added to the playable roster) are a bit of a mixed bag, and often require playtesting in order to determine what certain tiles do, or why two similar appearing tiles may have very different power costs. I'm sure this will improve as the game nears release.


Conclusion: This is an excellent indie space sim that melds the fun parts of designing ships with elements of RTS and simple asteroids-style gameplay. It is worth the $30 as is, and I'm excited to see the rest of what the developers pack in before it hits release.

reviewText:
Reassembly is a beautiful, enthralling top-down spaceship-builder/space combat game with sturdy mechanics and an intuitive building system that deserves the praise it has recieved.

The basic building blocks are two-dimensional shapes (guns, hull blocks, engines, and so on,) which are a joy to connect and shape into fighters, freighters, capital ships and stations. As the player becomes more experienced, new shapes unlock, leading to some truly impressive creations. What's more, the fleets that other players have made are imported onto the map as 'Agents', meaning that, in addition to the various types of standard enemies, the player has to go up against the creations of fellow players - controlled by the AI, but built by humans. Some of the are quite brilliant.

Unlocking the most expensive pieces can be a grind, and the game doesn't tutorialise nearly as well as it should (there is a fair bit of advice online), but after many hours I still find plenty to keep me busy.

And if you ever encounter one of my capital ships, here's a tip: keep astern. For the life of me, I can't seem to design a ship with a decent turning speed.

Reassembly is a game that has grown on me.

I helped back it in it's early alpha days, giving its kickstarter my $30 donation. I liked the look of it. Sandboxish, procedural generation, top-down arcade feel. I played the very early alpha version and was entertained for a few hours. I soon lost interest, and the game became stale to me.

Since then I've come back to the game again and again. It's one of those games you'll get pumped about and think about all day only to come home from work and play it till you drop. It's enjoyment for me comes in short bursts.

Recently I've made a discovery. The game does not play itself. People complain about how tedious it is to capture systems and hold them. They say something along the lines of Once you capture it there is no point. Your ships don't spawn there and you get no resources." Now listen here
date: that is where you are wrong.\n\nYou can build space stations that bristle with defenses and hold their own agains enemy capital ships. Alternatively
recommended: that space station can be covered in solar arrays to slowly farm you resources. Recently one of my favorite things to do is populate enemy territory with little "Outpost" stations via a factory on one of my ships. I then spend time fighting on the front line with my fleet to push the enemy out. This game is all about how you play it.\n\nIn summary
hoursPlayed: Reassembly is a great game. It's hard to find anything else out there even close to it (I think of S.P.A.Z. as the only other game that resembles it
voteText: another great by the way). Keep giving it a chance and you'll get a lot of replayability out of it. If you enter with a closed mind you'll get a closed off experiance. I highly recommend it."

reviewText:
2 hours in and I knew it was a great game, 15 hours in I had to tell others about it!  So here I am.

A 2D top down space shooter whilst accurate, is a poor description for this game as there is much more to it than that.  The graphics although basic are perfect for the game.  The sound is also well chosen.

You start in a pre-designed ship but as time goes on you can add to the design or just create a new one from scratch.  There are a decent variety of weapons and other modules to choose from, like rockets, missiles, torpedoes, mines, lasers, projectile based weapons and crazier ones.  Your ships can also house a factory to build other ships on the fly, which in turn can have a factory and can build.  With a bit of time you can have a fleet of AI controlled ships following you around until you dismiss them to do their own thing, and they do.  AI ships not under your control will continue to gather resources and contribute to your factions efforts.  Time to colonise and control the galaxy!

The map is large, and the factions varied, although I am now starting to get slightly bored of the existing factions, but there are many more in the Steam Workshop.

My only criticisms of the game are as follows; Agents, which are player made ships that spawn into the game and severely ruin your day, are often too good and numerous when they first appear.  You could ignore them until stronger, however once you give them a foothold in the galaxy they are really hard to remove.  In addition, you reach the endgame of progression in terms of unlocking blocks and maximum ship size too soon, normally after a couple of hours.

All being told, an excellent buy.

This game is a new drug.

This is exactly what it looks like. If you like what it looks like, you'll probably like playing it... Though expect a lot of your ships to fly awkwardly until you get used to building ships with the pieces you're given.

You know, I've been waiting for a game like this to appear. I love space, spaceships, and I love games where there's something that lets my creativity run wild. Glad I found this gem!

This is a game where you control a single ship of faction you choose at the beginning of the game. You can customize it however you want it with the pieces the faction provides. Each faction is unique in a way and none are the same. You fly around, you shoot enemies, gather resources, unlock new modules, grow in power, build up your ship to become an unstoppable destroyer, unlock other factions to play as, and so on.

Of course you don't need to fly alone, you can build up your fleet, or hire pilots from your faction to join you and fly with it. You'll soon be able to conquer the entire galaxy. Also, the galaxy has a fair amount of 'agents', which are fleets that were made by other players. Most of the ones I've seen so far were pretty formidable so if you see a red arrow, you should run until you really feel confident you'll break their ships with ease. Oh, and if you're done playing in that one galaxy you started in? Use a wormhole to fly to another one! This will also upload your current fleet, and chances are, someone, somewhere, on planet Earth, will be soon encountering your very own fleet on their computer. And he'll probably have trouble destroying you.

What's truly beatiful about this game is how simple it looks, and how complex it actually is. You could actually consider this game some sort of art. You start in a tiny sector, and you can see pretty early on how dynamic the world is. The AI harvests the minerals, grows in size, expands, it gets better with you, and so on. For example, I once built a single ship that could build stations. I manufactured it from my flagship, kicked it from the fleet so it could be independent, and guess what. Soon enough, when I came back, there were like, 15 stations there, and a whole lot of tiny little fighter ships scuttling around. It was an awesome sight. To be honest, the game kinda looks more organic than scientific. It's like actual organisms battling against each other. Sort of.

Well, either way, if you like space, spaceships, and space battles, if you like being creative, if you like shooting stuff up, if you like seeing your ship grow from a super fast tickling drone to a slow, massive hulking beast of absolute annihilation, if you like sending your enemies to oblivion, then chances are you're going to appreciate this game. It's got a fair amount of replayability, and even though it looks simple, it's really lots of fun.

Reassembly is, in a nutshell, spaceship editing and combat done right. The editor is a snap to do just about whatever you want to do. For example, you can copy your ship and stick the new one on the front of your original ship in less than 5 seconds if you're even halfway decent at using the keybindings. Another good thing is that you can change reassembly from a miminalistic game to a Tron-esque visual style, allowing you to run Reassembly on an old or new computer and use whatever RAM you have. And if you're STILL not convinced, it has mods. Overall, Reassembly gets a 19/20. If you're on the fence about it, buy it on sale for the price of three chocolate bars.

This is THE definitive lego game for lovers of space and starships.
It always surprises me when developers are able to boil the concept of 'fun' down to such a simple, gratifying level. And that is exactly what you get with this game; an intuitive fleet building experience where the fun doesn't stop when you hit the building menues.
I'd argue it starts there. Though admittedly half or so of my game-time was spent afk (as with most games I play), I have spent roughly 20 hours building ships, and maybe 5 actually cruising around. The 'tournament' style mode you can throw any ship you've been building into is incredibly rewarding, and oddly relaxing. Sitting back and watching the Dreadnaught you've spent an hour on go ripping through other people's lovingly crafted creations is a great system that both allows you to test out your ship against a variety of other players' designs, and serves as eye candy to the nth degree.

The game has a concept of 'agent' fleets, in which a fleet designed by other players invades your world. There is a peculiar feeling I get from this game that stems from this idea, and not even necessarily when I'm playing it. The fact that some poor player will at some point accidentaly have a run in with my fine tuned, massive killing machines gives me a sadistic pleasure that I would say is almost entirely unique to this game.

A gem of a game for people of all ages, and now that it has modding support added, who knows what can come out of this game.

A fun twin stick spaceship shooter with an organic feel to it similar to Pixeljunks Flow. You collect food called R(esource) and trade it for C(redits) to unlock new ship parts and raise your point allowance to stick more guns and thrusters to your ships body.

Damage taken is reflected on your ships, parts are removed and will regrow fairly quickly. Half your thrusters missing on one side of your ship? Have fun trying to escape without smacking right into the next obstacle. If you command block is destroyed you respawn at the nearest factory station or ship, while losing all R. No big deal, chances are you randomly crash you ship into the next asteroid at least a couple of times.

You expand territory for you faction by activating space stations and feeding them resources. Once you unlock the factory block you can start building your own fleet with your own designs, and even pop out your own stations. Massively fun for a bit but it's really a one trick pony.

The good
Controls are good, even though you can build clunky ships.
Ship Designs are fun and designing your own fleets is quite neat.
Lots of ship designs from user generated content, also workshop support now.
The Organic world with it feeding and growing cycle is sweet, even if only rudimentary.
Offer  at least 6-7 hours of good fun. More if you enjoy the editor, optimizing fleets and trying out the different races. I doubt we see much more support from the dev that adds more replyability, but you never know.


The bad
Controller support isn't complete, feels like 80% is there and the rest just never got done.
Tutorial is a joke, it just checks for input and a couple of conditions, I accidently skipped almost half of it in the first 3 seconds. At the very list it needs to disable other inputs and walk you though it step by step.
Simple block ship designs tend to do better than fancy. Wrong incentive.
Editor has a snap function for connecting parts, nice but it only works 50% of the time making it almost useless.
Some ship design are rather clunky and the AI does a good job of smashing into every solid body, Funny the first two times but it does get old really fast after that.
Low replayability, the simulation aspect of the world isn't really complex enough to allow for new situations to arise.


Looking forward to a sequel, I would love to see the core concepts of the game flashed out and some support for drop in multiplayer.

This game is horribly addictive. The basics: build your ship out of a set of parts and unlock new parts and weapons. This works so well that it got me playing 3 days straight without even touching another game. Players unlock new factions by killing capital ship from the latter and there are plenty of mods extending existing factions or adding new ones.

The gameplay is simple, weapons can be bound to mouse buttons or auto-fire, every faction has its specialities and different blocks with different stats and forms, the game seems quite balanced at the moment, I played 6 factions to max and did not yet encounter problems with balancing.

Graphics are simplistic but beautiful, the soundtrack is hypnotic and does not get annoying and there is a lots of physics involved, the game may slow down a bit during heavy battles.

This game gets a whopping 9.5 out of 10 for making everything it wants right.

This game is just 2D space-ship lego with lasers, missiles, and drones. But when you customise your ship and try to kill an agent, it would be 3 a.m..

Honestly, it's hard to take this game seriously. Sure, you begin said game with fairly easy-to-use controls and ship construction, but it turns into...well... Imagine a ship which spits out more ships which destroy ships so that the first ship could gain the resources to build more ships. See where I'm going with this? It becomes a matter of power and dominance, and eventually the AI simply cannot keep up with your Ingenuity. I built a ship that was precisely what I described. Sure, by itself, it wasn't ever going to last, but when the ship has reached a maximum of around 500 drones (fighters) and a full fleet of 70 entry-level skiffs, not so much. The point is that, in this game, one can gain absurd levels of power that they can used to destroy other absurd levels of power. Anyway, if anyone wonders what the game is all about and is happening to be reading my review, then allow me to enlighten you: You begin the game with a default ship in a default faction which can be used to capture stations (spawn locations), destroy other ships, or scavenge to gain the resources to level up to allow for more stuff to be packed onto your ship or gain more stuff to pack onto your ship. Such stuff usually consists of weapons, shielding, thrusters, drone launchers, factories, harvestors, generators, etc. which become harder to place on your ship if you don't level up or don't use enough power generators to use such stuff. Once you have the upgrades you need and you have the level, you have free reign to place as many of that item on your ship as you want for ****ing free, and that is what leads to gradually overpowered ships. My advice, just fly around in a custom ship equiped with default thrusters for days and capture every single station you can. As they are mostly unguarded, it's pretty easy to rank up doing that.

I played 24 hours of this game on one weekend, straight.

An AMAZING game. Small file, tons of ways to play.

One problem though: When capturing a space station that promptly becomes a spawnpoint, you may be killed fairly close to said spawn point. Once respawned, you will find the same asshat AI who killed you barreling through space to do so again and again, staying near your spawn and completely draining your C. Most times there is no way other than sheer luck and speed to outrun the douchepickle who is leaps and bounds ahead of you, but sometimes you are stuck there being vaporized over and over again with one guy floating relatively close to your station, mimicing a twelve year old spawn camping in Call Of Duty.

Otherwise it's a great game.

reviewText: Reassembly fits into my chill-out group of games. You can mindlessly tweak your ships, grow fleets, etc, and just explore the region. Once that region gets boring you can jump through the wormhole to a fresh new one. Over time the game does start to feel a little bland - once you get to the big ships and the big fleets with them, the challenge seems to go away. For that reason, that's why it's in my chill-out pile. It's Flow, with spaceships and some neat mechanics allowing you to change your ships, share your ships in other people's games, etc.

What else should I say about this game?
Basically it's a 2D space game where you have to make money by kiling other space ships, simple huh? Not really, because you get to make your OWN spaceship using different blocks. And because you do, so do other people, and their ships shown up in your game and destroy you. Boom. Unless of course, your spaceship is good enough to make theirs go boom.

Pros

Build you own spaceship
Blocks of stuff running around, how can that not be good
Beautiful textures
Fight the ships other people build
You get to waste too much time

Cons

Nothing, ok but the dev needs to add bigger maps and multiplayer.

This is, by far, the most fun I've had in a game recently.

Pros:
-Intuitive building system.
-Multiple factions, all with seperate strengths and weaknesses.
-Fast, exciting combat.
-Easy to mod/ modding support.

Cons:

Really great game massive preceedurally genrated maps means a lot to explore and conquer and a lot of options to build on and get creative with when designing a fleet, upon conquering worlds you may proceed to find new ones to conquer through wormholes, while sending your fleet to cause trouble for other players. On the other hand, this game requires a lot of time investment to get the full experience of ship evolution and territory expansion, I recommend Reassembly specifically players looking to be creative with their designs and put some time into doing so. Players who might enjoy this game might also be fans of Robocraft or Minecraft since this game runs on a similar concept as Minecraft while also having the creative building aspects of Robocraft.
Like Boss Constructor but so much better in every single way.

Decent Game. I love the idea. The building and the concept.

Sadly after you unlock everything the game gets stale very fast. There is nothing really to do at the end of the day. There is no goals or objective. Other than Agents that do not respawn, factions do not attack you and everything that is not in your area is inactive and dormant.

I don't think it was worth 15 bucks, but because i love this concept i hope the dev uses my money to make an even better sequal that has more depth and content.

Thanks.
Must have!
This is an excellent game to pass the time, and mods can make it into a great experience. 9/10

I have a total of just over 20hrs into the game. The first 15 were on an old windows computer where It was still very fun, but the graphics weren't as good as they could be and it lagged horribly whenever I went near the spiky yellow plants. Recently, I realized it was compatible with my brother's new Mac and the graphics were amazing and it only lagged when I made tournaments with hundreds of drone carriers.
Reassembly really has it all.

-Mac compatibility

It doesn't get boring 5/5

Honestly, it's hard to take this game seriously. Sure, you begin said game with fairly easy-to-use controls and ship construction, but it turns into...well... Imagine a ship which spits out more ships which destroy ships so that the first ship could gain the resources to build more ships. See where I'm going with this? It becomes a matter of power and dominance, and eventually the AI simply cannot keep up with your Ingenuity. I built a ship that was precisely what I described. Sure, by itself, it wasn't ever going to last, but when the ship has reached a maximum of around 500 drones (fighters) and a full fleet of 70 entry-level skiffs, not so much. The point is that, in this game, one can gain absurd levels of power that they can used to destroy other absurd levels of power. Anyway, if anyone wonders what the game is all about and is happening to be reading my review, then allow me to enlighten you: You begin the game with a default ship in a default faction which can be used to capture stations (spawn locations), destroy other ships, or scavenge to gain the resources to level up to allow for more stuff to be packed onto your ship or gain more stuff to pack onto your ship. Such stuff usually consists of weapons, shielding, thrusters, drone launchers, factories, harvestors, generators, etc. which become harder to place on your ship if you don't level up or don't use enough power generators to use such stuff. Once you have the upgrades you need and you have the level, you have free reign to place as many of that item on your ship as you want for ****ing free, and that is what leads to gradually overpowered ships. My advice, just fly around in a custom ship equiped with default thrusters for days and capture every single station you can. As they are mostly unguarded, it's pretty easy to rank up doing that.

This game is a simple concept expanded upon and made extremely entertaining (read: addicting). All you do is build a ship out of 2D shapes, shoot other ships, and try not to get blown up, all while making your blocky ship bigger and better. And yet, the game manages to do for me what even big-production space titles like Elite: Dangerous couldn't: absorb me in an expansive, living universe that I got hours of fun out of. It's easy to jump into, there's unlimited creative potential in making your ships, the destruction effects are satisfying, and you never run out of things to shoot, because the only thing there really is to do is expand your territory by destroying enemy ships, of which there are in (sometimes frustrating) abundance.\nThe passive mulitplayer" mechanic is enjoyable
date: because while you can't very well taunt over the wreckage of destroyed player ships hoping to give your enemy some quality killcam footage
recommended: you can still feel smug knowing you just trashed the MVP of someone else's universe without expecting them to come back for revenge.\nThe game world in its geometric minimalism is surprisingly atmospheric
voteText: and this feeling is certainly helped by the Brian Eno-esque music. There's no real plot that ties the 6 factions together as far as I know
helpfulPercent: but I feel like any kind of story would weigh down the smooth simplicity of the gameplay.\nAll in all
votesHelpful: Reassembly is probably the most fun you can have in space without doing cargo runs.\n\n(For bonus funtimes: Be the Sentinel. Get the Armor Spikes. Make buzzsaws. Be unstoppable.)"

reviewText: enjoyable, good potential

Reassembly is the game I never knew I wanted, but man, did I want it badly.

A 2D top-down shooter not unlike space invaders or asteroids in the sense that you fly around and shoot stuff. Reassembly takes it to a whole new level, allowing you complete customization of your ship. You can connect various parts, which snap together at points like legos, to create whatever your mind can come up with. At the beginning of a playthrough, your ships will be small and fairly weak, but as you advance you will be able to fly massive frigates followed by your very own custom fleet.

One of my favorite parts of ship creation is the physics of thruster placement. Where you put your thrusters actually matters a lot; your ship won't be able to turn very well if you only place them on the back. This also lets you build some funny creations such as ships that travel by spinning. It also means that if you are having trouble progressing, you can completely change the feel of your vehicle by moving or adding a thruster.

Creation aside, the game revolves around the aquisition of currency (called C") and resource (called "R"). You get both of these basically by blowing up your enemies
date: the other ship factions. You use your C to buy upgrades and new parts for your fleet
recommended: allowing you to take on bigger enemies. If you manage to conquer your whole galaxy
voteText: the game allows you to jump into a wormhole to enter a new galaxy with your fleet. You can also unlock new factions to play as; all of them utilize different base shapes for their ships
helpfulPercent: meaning you can create entirely new ideas playing one faction that you couldn't with another.\n\nIf you feel like you've peaked
votesTotal: sending it to other players' games as a powerful opponent called an Agent. This is a really great part of the game
votesFunny: it keeps things challenging and fresh.\n\nOverall
commentsCount: I put this game in the same circle as Spore. You create cool things and share it with others. The game is fun to look at
column16: very colorful
column17: and it has an awesome soundtrack. If you like building things
column18: if you like space
column19: or you like shooting the hell out of ships

reviewText:
Reassembly.

A game about building spaceships and fighting against AIs In a open galaxy.

You can design your own ships completely form scratch out of different parts.

There are 7 playable factions each with different parts to use.

If you like captain forever you will almost certainly like Reassembly.

You can collect resources from plants and build a fleetof your own to fight along side you.

Overall A very good game.

Definatly worth buying!

I played 24 hours of this game on one weekend, straight.


What are you waiting for?!

This is exactly what it looks like. If you like what it looks like, you'll probably like playing it... Though expect a lot of your ships to fly awkwardly until you get used to building ships with the pieces you're given.

You know, I've been waiting for a game like this to appear. I love space, spaceships, and I love games where there's something that lets my creativity run wild. Glad I found this gem!

This is a game where you control a single ship of faction you choose at the beginning of the game. You can customize it however you want it with the pieces the faction provides. Each faction is unique in a way and none are the same. You fly around, you shoot enemies, gather resources, unlock new modules, grow in power, build up your ship to become an unstoppable destroyer, unlock other factions to play as, and so on.

Of course you don't need to fly alone, you can build up your fleet, or hire pilots from your faction to join you and fly with it. You'll soon be able to conquer the entire galaxy. Also, the galaxy has a fair amount of 'agents', which are fleets that were made by other players. Most of the ones I've seen so far were pretty formidable so if you see a red arrow, you should run until you really feel confident you'll break their ships with ease. Oh, and if you're done playing in that one galaxy you started in? Use a wormhole to fly to another one! This will also upload your current fleet, and chances are, someone, somewhere, on planet Earth, will be soon encountering your very own fleet on their computer. And he'll probably have trouble destroying you.

What's truly beatiful about this game is how simple it looks, and how complex it actually is. You could actually consider this game some sort of art. You start in a tiny sector, and you can see pretty early on how dynamic the world is. The AI harvests the minerals, grows in size, expands, it gets better with you, and so on. For example, I once built a single ship that could build stations. I manufactured it from my flagship, kicked it from the fleet so it could be independent, and guess what. Soon enough, when I came back, there were like, 15 stations there, and a whole lot of tiny little fighter ships scuttling around. It was an awesome sight. To be honest, the game kinda looks more organic than scientific. It's like actual organisms battling against each other. Sort of.

Well, either way, if you like space, spaceships, and space battles, if you like being creative, if you like shooting stuff up, if you like seeing your ship grow from a super fast tickling drone to a slow, massive hulking beast of absolute annihilation, if you like sending your enemies to oblivion, then chances are you're going to appreciate this game. It's got a fair amount of replayability, and even though it looks simple, it's really lots of fun.

Reassembly is, in a nutshell, spaceship editing and combat done right. The editor is a snap to do just about whatever you want to do. For example, you can copy your ship and stick the new one on the front of your original ship in less than 5 seconds if you're even halfway decent at using the keybindings. Another good thing is that you can change reassembly from a miminalistic game to a Tron-esque visual style, allowing you to run Reassembly on an old or new computer and use whatever RAM you have. And if you're STILL not convinced, it has mods. Overall, Reassembly gets a 19/20. If you're on the fence about it, buy it on sale for the price of three chocolate bars.

amazing game!
when I first bought this game, I thought I had lost my money to some crap game, but as I got more into it, I figured it was well worth it and now I am hooked, not in a bad way though. The graphics have so many effects and the game play has a wide range of things you can do, from taking 60 mins lost in your world perfecting ships or going through worm hole after worm hole looking for other players ships to fight.

97% of the people like it any ways, that's a review itself
Give me one Good reason NOT to get this game 999/100 - Its more fancy than iggy. Probably one of my favorite games ever May be too good Imo ;3

Reassembly.

A game about building spaceships and fighting against AIs In a open galaxy.

You can design your own ships completely form scratch out of different parts.

take the very beginning of spore, the cell stage, upgrade that ten-fold,  use a spaceship asthetic, and you will get a good idea of what reassembly is. this game is really a lot of fun, especially if you like building things. there are different races you get to play, each with their own style, weapons, and blocks to use. during the game, you float around killing other ships and collecting resources. you take those back to stations and factories that can make more ships, and blob out from there to occupy more space. the more resources you collect, the more you can upgrade, and the size of your ship will progressivly get larger and larger. one fun side part of the game is just designing ships and having tournaments with them. finding out what designs work in different situations and adjusting your current blueprints to fit within a certain size can be very addicting. do you want a slow chugging armored beast, or a superlite speedy sniper? in the end its up to you, and the amount of designs that you can create are literally endless.

This game is amazing !

I love playing this game. HUGE variety, many ways to build your fleet and evolve, many ways to aproach an Agent ( aka Boss ) , diffrent weapones for diffrent playstyles like :
-You like to be a close-range brawler to take the battles up close and personal ? Get alot of shields, armor and flak cannons!
-You like to be a long-range sniper to take out targets from afar? Take the lasers ! ( add alot of them or they won't be effective )
-You like to be a huge capital ship ? Take all the big guns and all the small guns and all the shields and put them all up in one enormous ship! ( will take quite a while )
-You like beign a sneacky beacky invisible guy? Well , you can't, sorry.
-You like to be a miner of some sort ? Take a harvester on your ship and fly around !
-You like to be everything above? Farm for 100 hours to get extra C and P and then you will be able.
And, the destruction, effects and even graphics are AMAZING!
WELL DONE!
I loved playing this game, totally worth picking up, it includes all types of cool ships!

The only problem is that the game is single-player, so COOP mode would be an amazing feature and I hope the developers will add it!

But still,
10/10 !
Amount of time building ships: 95%\nAmount of time flying ships: 5%
crazy fun game with supprising depth, worth every penny.

reviewText: Its like building LEGO spaceships, except this time they blow stuff up for you.

My fleet was awesome - a great array of plasma cannons, anti-matter cannons and factory ships. Every enemy and every faction ship I encountered was toast. I come across a wormhole. Sure. Let's go through. I am invincible!

I am in my primary ship without my fleet - that's cool, my ship is awesome. I can take on anything!

I encounter an agent for the first time. Deep purple and pink. Fast, manuverable and they hit very hard. My best ships cannot defeat them. What have I done moving into this wormhole?! Every station I claim soon becomes this mysterious purple agent's. I have nothing left, and will be hunted down forever!

I feel like quitting the game and starting again. What a waste of time! My game has been ruined by some OP fleet! I give the game a rest.

But naturally I come back to the game. There is something in the game that beckons me very strongly.

The ship editor.

Needless to say, after a few minor adjustments to my fleet, I was pulverising that silly purple fleet to dust. I look at my 20+ fleet of familar designs and think, yes! This is awesome!

This is my first review. I have never felt compelled to write a review about any game. And then, this one comes along...

There is something very satisfying about meeting challenges and designing your way to victory.  Reassembly is THE game for people like me. If you love designing spaceships,endless variety, strategy and just plain fun, get this game! I cannot reccommend this game enough.

This is a surprisingly fun game.  But, although there is a tutorial, it needs to be more explicit.  That is, at least for me, when I started playing and I was exhausted and sleepy and mostly dead to the world I needed the tutorial to really drill into my head the basics of the game.  How do you repair your ship? It repairs itself.  How do you gather materials?  I'm still not quite sure. . .  maybe add a 'Gatherer' to your ship, shoot lots of enemies and absorb space debris by tractor field.

I've had this game a while now, and I can't ever seem to be able to drop it. Every time I reach the endgame in one faction, I start again in another. The game is limitless, and so perfectly well done. If I could, I would give this game an 50/10. Of course, it's not for everyone, but if you like survival games with lots of progressions, sandbox games, and such, then I would recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game has been a pleasent surprise. Noticed only a couple small bugs so far. Half the time I'm just plotting my next ship or a counter to something that tore my last idea in half. Needs more factions and less skating on ice feeling when flying. Otherwise definately worth it.

Pros:
~ Easy to learn controls and UI
~ Game mechanics/speed is more or less controlled by the player
~ Different factions with different building materials offer a different feel.
~ Custom colors, I hate when you have to look a certain way.
~ So many different ways to build your fleet! I felt like a kid again watching my legos come alive haha.

Things I wanted to mention that aren't so positive:
~ Ive noticed some of the stations don't build themselves after capturing the node. They sit idle until I edit them, after I edit they will grow and start to function.
~ I mentioned the feeling of skating on ice. even with well placed thrusters its still hard to control your ship.
~ In ine point of the tutorial the game asks you to build a ship with a ship with a factory and then have that ship produce another to complete the cycle to grow your fleet. I love this idea but after you've made the first one spawn they dont really expand they all kinda stay in the same spot :*( I gave them thrusters to move! go kill stuff! Anyways.

8/10 Great fun.

reviewText: Reassembly and Gimbal are my two favorite 2D arcade shooters where one can design their own ships.  The moment I saw this game I thought of Gimbal and knew I had to have it.  Graphics-wise Reassembly is not quite as detailed, but the particle physics are beautiful!  Reassembly makes is very easy to design one's own ships on the fly, and offers procedural content that keeps things fresh.  This game is certainly worth the price and I highly recommend it to any gamer that enjoys a 2D space shooter with almost endless customization!

reviewText:
Very interesting game. I picked it up on the recommendation of a Steam friend of mine who has similar taste in games.   I wasn't sure what to expect but I can say the game is addicting.  I started it up with the intention of playing for 5-10 minutes just to see what it was like and the next thing I know it was three hours later.

Graphically the game has style, though it is somewhat hard to tell from the screenshots that I have seen.  I personally like the vector graphic look and reminds me of Asteroids which I played the heck out of in my younger years.  The game is a bit hard to get into and I am sure I am going to have to watch a number of vidoes to understand all the concepts but it is easy enough to play with and pick up enough to enjoy.

This is one of those games that you just have to play for ourself to see how addictive it is.

10/10

reviewText: I don't often find a game that I can't put down - but this is one. Now officially my favorite chill-out game. It's a strategy game set in a rich living world. Design your ship from scratch using basic building blocks. Pilot it round a large area of space using Newtonian physics - i.e. you carry on moving in the same direction once you have built up speed, without further thrust, and regardless of the direction you are pointing. The game uses a wrap-around map. Harvest resources, trade them to improve your spacecraft. Fight enemies and try to take space sectors from other factions. Recruit allies and form a fleet. Put a factory on your ship and spawn new ships. Travel to other maps using wormholes". Fight other players' uploaded fleets (not true multiplayer but a contest of designs). You can also use the wormholes to upload your own fleet designs. Unlock new factions to play.\n\nYou could make it a fast and furious battle or a leisurely affair - up to you. I'm 9 hours in and feel I'm only just beginning to scratch the surface. A real indie masterpiece and a credit to the developers."

reviewText:
tl;dr Spore meets SubSpace (aka Continuum), 8/10. Remember SubSpace? Need I say more? I do? Okay.

As others have said, this game is extremely addictive. In a good way. The ship editor in itself is hours of lego-style building fun, but add to that a really immersive single-player world with player-made ships and you have a game that is both simple and compelling at the same time.

Definitely worth the money, tons of replayability. Summarizing my experience as follows:

Pros:
- Great physics / destructable levels, and combat is super fun.
- Awesome soundtrack.
- World is huge but not infinite. That's a good thing for a space game.
- Building ships is surprisingly fun. I'm not usually the type to want to buy a game then spend hours in an editor customizing things. The editor is very featureful and forgiving (undo, redo, copy paste), unlike many other in-game editors out there.
- Sending your ship into a wormhole uploads your fleet into the ether so they can be run in other player games as the bad guys, Spore-style! In other words, tons of player-made content.
- If you get sick of your world, fly into a wormhole and explore a parallel dimension instead.

Cons:
- Controls are a little quirky, especially on gamepads. Don't use a gamepad. Occasionally you'll find yourself slamming into an asteroid and getting completely stuck because the fly backwards" key gets completely rotated and you and up flying into the asteroid and flailing around until you're killed by a passing enemy.
- Ship editor is missing a MANUAL test flight option to get a sense of the maneuverability of the ship you spent an hour making.
- Ship editor is missing important info about total mass / total thrust / total energy created which could help to approximate the above stuff. Only total resource capacity is listed-- everything else you have to calculate yourself.
- NO MULTIPLAYER! The player-made content is fun in SP
date: but a game like this just begs for multiplayer.\n- Once you've maxed out points
recommended: Actual gameplay is 1-dimensional. Mostly consists of flying around and shooting everything you see-- or if you're like me and setup auto-fire
hoursPlayed: it's just flying around and letting the ship shoot everything for you. You can explore to find new bases
voteText: but that doesn't really give you anything.\n\nOn the last two points
helpfulPercent: I wonder if I'm just misunderstanding some of the game dynamics
votesHelpful: but it seems like unlocking bases is just there to occupy your time. I also don't really know if you can ever wipe out another faction. It would be great if:\n\n- You could watch bases expand over time
votesTotal: including size and number of ships
votesFunny: so you actually have more allies flying around. Ditto for enemies that go unchecked.\n- You could actually attack enemy bases and eventually wipe out factions. It would be awesome if each faction actually had a stronghold base you have to kill in order to wipe out an enemy.\n- There were new factions added over time
commentsCount: including to existing regions. Maybe I haven't played for long enough
column16: but it seems like the same factions just exist in perpetuity.\n\nThere it is. Lots of cons because the pros seem obvious to me. It's damn fun! It could be even better if the above things were addressed."

reviewText:
Reassembly is a fantastic game. In practice its very much a twin-stick-shooter, though it retains a surprising amount of depth for a game which is so simple at its heart.

There are many things that make this game great, but to simplify things for this small review, and to add information to anyone on the fence on weather to buy it or not, i will put these points into separate short sections.

1) Ship Building.

The core mechanic of the game, building your ship is both rewarding and a time sink. When building the largest ship in my fleet, i spent 40min before i was satisfied with the end result. But when i was satisfied, i was very satisfied. I glowed with pride as i flew my behemoth through space.
The fun doesn't stop there. The ship is made up of lots of different parts, as you can see from the imagery. At first you would be forgiven for assuming that this is simply a method of allowing design flexibility. While this holds true, it opens up an interesting mechanic. You see, every part of the ship is a separate entity. A finished ship is less a single unit, and more a collection of blocks stuck together. In practice this means that slapping hull plating to your ship doesn't simply increase health, but creates an armored point wherever you placed it. Weapons have less health, so placing them in your ship created areas of vulnerability. If you gun is destroyed, you cant fire. If your jets are destroyed you cant move. This means that the layout of your ship is as important as what you put in.
Equally, your jet engines work as individual units, rather than just giving your ship '+movement speed'. So, if you don't have any jets placed at an angle, you cant turn. If you have no jets on your sides, you cant strafe. No jets facing forwards means you cant reverse. In this same vein, the more boosters you have, the faster you move.
All these points turn ship building into a sort of puzzle game. Though one in which the answer is what your preferred gameplay style is.

2) Combat.

While general space exploration is a big part of the game, combat is the fly in the soup of game mechanics here. (Not in a bad way, as everyone will want one). Combat is simple as it is deep. At its heart, you pick your target, align guns, and fire till dead. But on a deeper level there's alot which goes into combat. Every ship has a 'core'. This is your command bridge, your heart. When this goes, you die. Until it goes, you will regenerate parts slowly. So when approaching an enemy you look for the quickest way to take out this heart. With the variety of ships on offer, this never gets old.

3) Pacing.

The game is fantastically paced. Tutorials are done on the fly, so you learn by playing. At the start, you have a small ship. You gain resources by exploring, with small dogfights along the way. You use these resources to improve, and eventually you have a medium ship. Now you start fighting abit more and getting a better income from doing so, whilst supplementing you income with exploration. Then you get a big ship. Now exploration becomes the back seat. Combat is your bread and butter. You fight and fight. After abit, you enter the forth stage of progression. You may have dabbled, but until now you've been focused of improving yourself. Now you build a fleet. Soon your at the heart of a 30 ship strong armada, and fights take on a whole new focus.

The fantastic thing about this formula of progression is with the unlocks. There are alot of races (8?). You start with only 1. To unlock others you must locate and destroy a ship worth 1000 points (you start with around 300 and grow to 8000 so i found i was doing this around the second / third stage). Each race has some unique items and generally some sort of separate theme to its shared items. This allows great re-playability.

---------------------------

So, the review summery. This is a great game. Part Space exploration, part space combat, part lego. I'd advise this to alot of people, as there is something for everybody. In particular i'd point people to it who enjoy games with creation elements, such as Spore. If creation isnt your thing, but you like space combat sims, i would still advise this game. The races come with pre-made ships, and the game has the ability to export ships as code. So you can always trawl forums to locate ships.

I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
I don't write many reviews, but when I do I like to write them for games I like. This is one of those special games that I will take the time out of my day to write a few words about.

First: off I love how there are three different control schemes for the game, you don't realize how important this is untill you try all three. It is exceedingly useful because not all ships will work with one control set up.

Second: it's an interesting idea to have the universe populated with other players ships. It makes the game fresh. There are some problems with this system, for instance if you make a really weak ship and it is put into someone else's game it's pointless, but for the most part it's good.

Third: the building system, now this system has some major problems, mainly because I have not used it enough to completely understand the logic behind it. I will try to explain the good things it does and the problems it has. It functions like the builder in banjo and kazooie nuts and bolts the difference is it's two dimensional and you have a keyboard and mouse so it isn't frustrating to manipulate It for the most part its balanced, I think it would help if the basic blocks had a cost, for instance I made a cube with the faction you start with and though it's slow it is almost unbeatable because it has so much armor. This could be fixed if the basic parts had a low cost, maybe raise the cap to 10k and make the prices on the other parts higher so it evens out. The biggest problem with the building system is the blocks have to be exactly aligned for them to snap together, basically imagine legos but the pegs are the sizes of needles and you are making giant ships. This ends up with blocks that are a few pixels off of being perfect, this bugs me to death, it's probably the biggest problem with this game.

Fourth: The plant faction is too op, it is too easy to make a swarm of ships and to overrun any opponent you may have.

Fifth: Another amazing thing this game does well is the different factions have different base blocks, for instance there is a faction that is focused on triangles, this forces you to build intelligently.

There are many more things in this game that are worth a mention but if you made it to this point I will sum up my opinion on this game with, a resounding recommendation. All though it has it's problems the game as a whole is fun and for 15$ there is almost no reason not to buy it, I have played almost thirty hours of it at the point of writing this reviews, thats fifty cents and hour I have bought triple a games that are less enjoyable than this( looking at you tomb raider, Shadow of mordor, farcry 4, and many others).
