reviewText:
Props to the developer.

Reassembly is a well-put together, astonishingly beautiful game in it's simplicity. It's music is calming, the gameplay is smooth (aside from the problems -list to follow), and it's very interesting in the way that the factions each have their own preferred ship pieces. Command Mode is very interesting, and I would love to see an ability to command ships and assign Generals who Command their ships under your order. As well, the ability to force all currently active ships to change to the ship you want, and the ability to force all your Stations to spawn your preferred ships (because flying to each ship/station to edit them individually is impossible), would be great.

However, aside from the positive, Reassembly suffers from a few issues that are not just annoying, but are also game-breaking. They aren't too common to come across, but you will find them at some point.

These problems are:
1) Losing an entire fleet, which you've spent hours building up, in an instant. This needs to be changed. Reassmbly shouldn't just be about grinding for R (Resources), it should be about building fleets and going into enemy territory to conquer them.
2) Conquering fleets is great, but what of conquering sectors of space? Hours have been spent flying through a sector and murdering countless fleets only to then have realized that that single sector is still not conquered.
3) A.I.'s spawn kill users, especially if there are enough powerful enemy ships around. We are not given a buffer time to escape from numerous enemies lingering all over the Stations (when we're spawned in, they just annihilate us in seconds). This problem is infuriating, especially after just Starting up the game from a save and 10 enemies are literally sitting there, waiting for the user. A way to fix this issue (if not to give the user a buffer time) would be to check for the time in which it took for a player to get murdered after their last death, and if it's a very short period of time between deaths, the player should be spawned at a Station a few clicks away.

If you play the game for long enough, you'll experience these issues and side with my opinion that the game needs these fixes as soon as possible.

But again, this game is amazing. I would definately recommend it!

reviewText:
Reassembly doesn't seem like much on the surface; it could be made in flash, from the looks of it, at least in the screenshots on the store page. It looks and plays like a bunch of other games you might have played, like Void Hunter or even Bubble Tanks. It offers a simple 2-d playing field and unrealistic arcade-style space combat, but I can unequivocally say that this game is the best $15 I've ever spent on Steam, and that isn't hyperbole.

In Reassembly, you pilot a spaceship. Fly it around, collecting resources from the withering remains of the SPACE PLANTS which sprout from GIANT ASTEROIDS and which reproduce by shooting SEED MISSILES at other asteroids. Filled your tanks with resources? Head over to the local GIANT SPACE STATION and trade them in for CREDITS, with which you can purchase new ship parts, increase the maximum number of useful parts you can slap on your ship, and add other ships to your fleet. You fly around a gigantic galaxy filled with hundreds of sectors and 15 different factions of ships, all at war with you and each other, and each with their own quirks. Go to the north and you might find yourself embroiled in a battle against the strange plant-like faction which sprouts from asteroids, colonizes everything nearby, and rains down a hail of missiles against anything that gets too close. To the east there might be the regenerating red faction, which boast beam weapons and drones and hull plates which reassemble themselves even as you blast them away. To the south you can fight the white rectangular faction, which you can find sprouting off of asteroids deep inside their home sectors. And to the west you might be utterly decimated by the gigantic gunbricks of some other minmaxing schmuck who also bought this game.

Yes, you heard me right. If you manage to fight your way to a wormhole and upload your fleet, your fleet (without your control) can turn up in someone else's game to decimate their galaxy or provide fodder for whatever monstrous ships they've been cooking up.

Which brings me to the gem of this game: the ship designer. Each ship is comprised LEGO-style of multiple blocks with different shapes and functionalities. Each faction has different blocks; the default faction (others are unlocked when you destroy a 1000-point (or more) ship of theirs, while others are NPC-only) favors rectangles and triangles, while others favor diamond shapes or parallelograms or squares. You can design your ship from the ground up; the only thing that has to be included in a design is the tiny 1x1 square which is the command center - this also serves as a sort of last chance, as everything besides this component regenerates after it takes damage, at varying rates. Take a lot of damage but leave with your command center intact and you can regrow your whole ship all in a minute or so, or suck components in with a tractor beam if they or a substitute are floating nearby.

The gameplay is very sandboxy, but there's enough variety in enemy types and ship designs to sustain it. While I'd be happier with the playable factions having more components to play around with, as it is I've already put quite a few hours into the game and I plan to play a whole lot more. The main objective is to conquer the galaxy by converting each sector to your faction (indicated by color), and this can only be done by destroying the inhabitants of the sector. If you get destroyed by enemy fire (which happens frequently) you respawn back at the nearest ship with a factory component. There are stations scattered across the map which also have a factory component and are vastly powerful, but which lie dormant and deactivated; flying near them and reactivating them not only earns you a lot of credits, but it establishes a foothold for your faction in the sector.

You can equip your own ships with a factory and build your own fleet (with no maximum cap, I might add) by sucking in resources. As soon as the factory is on your ship, you stop shipping off your resources to every other ship and station with a factory inside tractor range, but start sucking it out of every other friendly ship with no factory in the area, and with those resources you can create a mighty fleet out of any designs you can think of. They'll fly with you, protect you, bring you resources, let you sell them for credits, and generally be your stalwart comrades until you're destroyed, at which point they leave your fleet and you have to start from scratch.

Reassembly isn't without faults; an option to turn off the player-made 'agent' fleets would be nice, but overall I am incredibly pleased with my purchase and as far as I'm concerned I've already made my money back and more.

reviewText:
If you like construction and customization, building a fleet of ships, leading your fleet into huge battles with other players' fleets for the sake of expanding your galactic empire, buy this game.

Don't let the 2d vector graphics throw you off. Reassembly is a relaxing game with a great soundtrack, infinite creativity, and great battles.

Several different factions, all with a different selection of weapons and hull blocks, gives much more replayability and keeps the gameplay from getting repetetive. The real fun is the ship building, though. Test your ships in simulated battles against other players' designs, and then use them in the game.

Basically if you ever dreamed of building and commanding a fleet of spaceships, you will love this game.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game. It has it's limits, but is definitely fun.

Video review:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5dDObkYTzJE&list=UURPe3hzgc7y8NTczf8AffDg

What is it?

Reassembly is a ship building game. Your goal is to design the most effective warship and conquer the sector. Of course, you're not alone here. There are factions that control territory in the sector. You belong to one faction and most others are hostile, although there are a couple neutral factions.

Gamplay consists of designing your vessel using preset parts. In the beginning of the game, you'll most likely spend your time gathering rescources that are generated by the local fauna and bringing it back to your factions stations. You will exchange the rescources for credits that allow you to purchase new ship parts and also alow you to build a bigger ship. Later, you'll likely build a warship capable of using the resources you collect to build your own fleet and wreak havoc on the opposing factions.

Your faction will grow and expand out into the sector and become stronger and you design ships to be put into your fleet. Once your done with one sector, you can enter a wormhole and enter a whole new sector.

Pros:

-The ship building system is simple and easy to use. Putting together a ship is as simple as a drag and drop experience.

-The graphics look amazing. Despite being simple polygon graphics, they really are captivating. The light show that a large battle creates is quite a sight to see.

-You have choice about what you will do. You can choose to be anything form a simple harvester to a fearsome dreadnaught.

-Competition within your own faction. As you bring back rescources, your station builds ships. These ships then go out in search of rescources. This will force you farther and farther from the safety of your station. I find that interesting.

Cons:

-Despite what the devs may say, there kind of is one way to build a good ship. The armor plating pieces do not count towards the size of your ship. The best way to build a good battleship is to slap on as much armor as you can.

-There is no interaction with the factions. There are no quests, no diplomacy, and no alliances. The only path to victory is conquest.

-Grinding. In order to build a large ship, you will have to harvest a lot of rescources. If you don't build a big ship, you will always dies. Put two and two together.

Really, this game boils down to trying to build the most powerful ship. That's enjoyable, and the exploration (at least before you've seen everything there is to see) can  be quite interesting. I doubt that I'll play this game far into the future, or that (in this current state) it will remain a big thing for long. However, it is still a good game and I've definitely enjoyed playing it.

reviewText:
Despite anything in the game that feels familiar, I have never played anything quite like Reassembly.

You might describe it as a mish-mash of SPAZ, Spore, and some other top-down space shooters, but the similarity ends there.  The procedurally generated 'galaxy' is full of varied enemies and dangers, and if you run out of baddies, you can dive into a wormhole for a fresh world.  Wormholes have another use, more on that below.

The main draw of the game though is the ability to build your own ships.  The ship editor is easy to learn, and has enough geometric shapes to allow you to produce anything you want.  The playable factions have different available hull and weapon choices, making each one it's own playstyle.  There is a progression curve, you must spend money earned in the world to unlock new weapons and increase the power cap limiting how much goes on your ship.  It doesn't take too long to max it out though, allowing for huge many-beweaponed designs.  You can also build space stations, it's as simple as building something with no thrusters and at least one factory.

Once you have some custom ships you like, hit up a wormhole.  Instead of following it to a new world, you can choose to upload a copy of your fleet roster while staying in your own world.  This uploaded fleet will then start randomly appearing in other players worlds.  These are called Agent fleets, and fighting other people's creations that appear in your world can be challenging and exciting.  I've encountered ships that were nearly unbeatable, forcing me to change my ships and tactics in order to prevail.

You needn't fly solo in your world either, you can equip a factory block and spend resources you collect to spawn AI controlled ships from your collection.  I'm not sure if there's a limit to how many ships you can have at once, I've gotten up to about 15 or so, plus a hundred or so drones if I'm in my Galactica carrier.  Tearing around space with a dozen ships blasting anything you target is super effective.

A caveat to mention is that there isn't any actual multiplayer, which would be great if it were possible, I can see why it would be difficult with all the physics objects that can occur.  Maybe a sequel could pull it off.  Also there are situations that cause the game to slow down significantly, particularly in Spikey Plant sectors once they start firing projectiles all over the place.

Many games out there let you build things, which is fine, but this is one of the few that lets you use and enjoy the fruits of your labor in actual gameplay.  The vector-style graphics are used to good effect and really get my nostalgia going.  I've only owned the game a couple weeks and have dumped almost 50 hours into it.  It's got good music too.

Grade A most excellent game 8000/10

reviewText:
TL;DRI don't usually write reviews, so please excuse the brevity, and rest assured that I do not flippantly say this:

I wholeheartedly recommend this game.


Slightly longer versionI got this game during a Humble Bundle sale (still ongoing, as of 2015-08-17), which was the first time I had ever heard about it. So, basically, I installed this game out of idle curiosity. The following are my impressions from playing it for a couple of hours. If you want to know more about what this game actually IS, I recommend reading some other reviews, or watching a video or two.

Pro: It is really fun. Fly, shoot, collect resources, build, shoot some more, re-build from scratch, collect more resources, fly and shoot even more. For me, this game fills a gap I did not know I needed filled, somewhere between StarBound/Terraria (for the block-like, 2D assembly of things) and Space Engineers (for finding yourself trying to build something you couldn't even imagine when you started playing), but actually nothing like either.

Pro: Pretty clever take on what you might call asynchronous multiplayer" -- while playing
date: you can upload your current ship (or fleet) at wormholes

reviewText:
Notice how the reviews with a lot of hours are the ones rating this game negatively? That's becase those reviews are informed and the people making them have seen all of what the game has to offer, which suffice to say isn't that much.
The game feels unfinished, and for a while I assumed it was still in early access, Because it certainly feels like one. Whilst I did enjoy what was there for as long as it kept me interested, there is too much room for improvement that hasn't been expanded into.

I've read their kickstarter, and the majority of things they have promised have not been delivered on, So for now I'm giving it a negative review. It's a decent game, but after around 30 hours what little content there is becomes stale, this isn't acceptable for the price they're asking.

Building space ships is certainly fun, but will only tide you over for as long as it keeps you interested, because as far as the base game goes, there is little to no end game other than rofl-stomping anything with massive lag inducing fleets, it feels very unrewarding. There is no reward for becoming the last existing race in the map either, even though that seems like what they're trying to push you towards.

In the arena however, fighting higher C tiers" your space ships become less "Ships" and more cubes of death. One of the main points the dev brings up in the video is that "There's no best way to build a space ship" which simply isn't true. Some design philosophies trump others
date: and function will always win over form
recommended: even a mixture of both.\n\nThere's also a many bugs that irk me
hoursPlayed: and still haven't been fixed after so long. The user interface is still terrible

column17: unless you save or overwrite the ships directly to the disk every time you make a change to the design
column18: there's a high probability that you'll missplace the blueprint in game and possibly lose it. An example for me was when I overhauled one of my designs

reviewText:
I purchased this as part of a Humble Bundle. I'm not the typical target audience for such a game and thus those who are will proabably not find this review helpful. I also know I'm in the minority on this game. Reassembly has a 94% approval rating. I'm in that 6%.

Given that approval rating it means that it is the player and not the game. It's probably done well but it is simply not my style of game. I find the controls confusing, the objectives unclear or poorly explained and I have no Earthly idea what is going on. If there is a deeper game here than running around and firing a weapon at targets that move too quickly to be hit, I haven't found it and the game isn't inspiring enough to make me want to look for it.

Come again, Blackadar? What does that mean? Ok, simply put I can't tell what's going on. I see blobs and shapes on screen. It has an art style that just doesn't register with me. I feel like I'm looking at a Jackson Pollock painting in hyper-motion. While I like Jackson Pollock, I don't exactly understand what I'm looking at when I look at that art. I don't understand what I'm looking at when I look at the screen on Reassembly. Now when I combine that with things moving so quickly on screent that I can't hit them, my gameplay options kind of narrow quickly.

Actually, they narrow into one thing - uninstall and go find a game I can play. Like Peggle. Or Uno. (it's a joke people, check my profile!)

I guess my ability to effectively control a twin-stick shooter in an abstract art style game is nonexistent. It does, however, have the distinction of being the highest rated game in my collection that I've given a thumbs down to. So if you like the genre this is probably a fine game. If you are like me and you don't enjoy this genre all that much, this won't change your mind.

reviewText: While I had some fun playing this game, it's ultimately flawed. There's not much point to it, and there's a couple of derpy aspects: firstly the parts aren't all geometrically compatible. For example, the octagonal parts aren't on the same size grid as the square parts. The rectangular parts are on a different size grid again. That's just dumb. Then there's the reason I just rage-quit: I was being single-shot killed in my most armored ship (surrounded by shields and at least 2500 armor) by a weapon (I assume it's a weapon) that I couldn't even see, let alone buy in upgrades. Just a big boom, and my big ship is insta-dead. That's just massively un-fun.

reviewText:
I... honestly have no idea what's even going on this game. Everything happens so fast and without explanation, tutorial objectives seemingly completed for a reason I can't really determine just because I happened to blink at the wrong time. If it's not that, I'm getting annihilated in 1-2 hits by any opposing ship, unable to defend myself because the default selection provided is so painfully underwhelming.

Scrapping and building from scratch isn't viable, either, the starting weapons absolutely worthless and block shapes that aren't particularly conducive or varied enough for sensible building in the long run. Could you theoretically grind for resources to eventually build the ship you want? Sure, but it seems counterintuitive when the core direction is undoubtedly combat.

That's not to say Reassembly is completely flawed, of course; the music and art direction are indeed very good and it is a neat idea overall, just not very well executed.

reviewText:
It reminds me of Spore. You start with very small amounts of building points with which to design your ship. You also haven't unlocked the better tech. It's a cool game but you run out of content pretty quickly and it starts to feel predictable and grindy. Then you kind of max out your ship and that's pretty much it I suppose.

There seems to be a multiplayer" mode where you can see the ships of other people on your friends list with the game and automate cpu vs cpu fights in those ships to see who will come out on top. The ship AI is basically to fly directly and as quickly at the opponent as possible so if you have close range weapons you could do pretty well here.

Not that any of it matters. There's not much else to the game. No interesting easter eggs. No special fun ways of being creative. It's pretty bland. A game like this really needs someone to write a story and make some interesting and unique characters to play parts in that story. Like it is now (and undoubtably forever) this game feels kind of not worth it. If you can get it for a dollar or two maybe...

reviewText: I do like the game but the in game different factions are radically unblanced and the ultimate ship is essentially a cube or rectangle with a bunch of weapons and engines.  There are some creative powerful ships out there but they are few and far between.  In specific i am almost constantly up against an agent called the lasercube, and its ♥♥♥♥ing boring as hell because i essentially have to break out a long range super fast sniping ship and kite it to death or make a clone of it, produce several of them and just out laser cube the laser cube.  This is also annoying.  Of course some faction arent even able to snipe things.  The faction that is orange red yellow has such weak hulls that the laser cube destroys them on sight, and with no long range weapons, and no shields the ROY (red yellow orange) faction is weak as balls against the others.  Its really annoying when my fleet of 7 or more 4000 cost ROY ships just get blown to ♥♥♥♥ by an agent looking at them the wrong way.  In short its a cool game, i do enjoy it, it just frustrates the crap out of me because the factions are unblanced as ♥♥♥♥, all the agents i see are basically cubes or rectangles, and I purchased the game right before the price dropped to $15.  As it stands if the price drops again, or if the game is somehow rebalanced to make cubes and rectangles not the most effcient ship design, or to somehow award ships with greater aestetic appeal more functionality, or really just something to balance all the factions and make them all equally capable of fighting with eachother, then I can recomend the game.  As it stands I would say buy it if you enjoy playing with legos a lot, and if legos weren't one of your favorite toys then this isn't for you as of right now.  I also noticed a lot of reviews talking about crashing and deleting save files but i never had those problems.  Not sure why, but those need to be fixed.

Poor instruction. Poor UI and poor gameplay.

Every ship drags out and drifts so much that thrusters are really only to propel and fling you in one direction while you wait to crash into something constantly. Simply put, the inertia is very poor.

Certainly a regrettable purchase. Legitimate buyer's remorse. Don't let the trolls saying it's good and downvoting anyone saying otherwise tricking you into buying this poorly made and hollow game.

reviewText:
I have to say that before I purchases this game, I was kind of nervous about how it would be, though it had some really good reviews. I soon found out that those reviews lived up to the positive nature.

Starting out as a single faction to pick, and a basic little ship, you start out a bit causious, trying to gather resources to build your ship up and try to take control of the map with a fleet of your own design along side you.

I have to say that one thing that really impressed me is how optimized this game really is. It might seem like the simple nature of just polygons and other shapes would run smooth, but the effects and lighting that can take place during a large battle between many ships can cause your system to lag. Surprisingly though, it takes several hundred ships in that battle before it really starts to take any effect.
The most addictive game I've ever played.

I love this game. Spent hours, no days building and optimizing spaceship designs. This is a designer's game.

Pros:
-The controls are flexable so you can fly however you want, a very welcome feature in these top down 2D games.
-The attention to detail in physics is incredible, e.g. if your ship has no off-axis thrusters, it turns really slowly.
-Open ended - no one strategy to dominate. You can go for speed, armor, shields, range, or build cost. Or you can just be a farmer or a gatherer.
-Multiple races - just when you think you've optimized a ship series for a particular race, you can play a different race with different abilities and different parts!
-Really pretty
-Self-building ships: the trouble with other building games (e.g. StarMade) is that you always have to rebuild your ship after a battle. In this game you don't worry about that, although there are design strategies for having your ship regenerate faster.
-Good combat AI, so you're not frustrated with the AI pilots being idiotic which breaks many other games.
-Ability to customize the build sequence of allied ships and stations

Would like to see:
Fleet vs fleet battles with the asynchronous mulitplayer! There are ways to do this with the sandbox but it's not very accessible.
Better (maybe customizable) combat AI: e.g. turning the ship to hide damaged armor or shields from enemy fire while it regenerates, or maybe being able to specify a preferred range of engagement.
Better non-combat AI: Having AI ships being more exploratory would be nice, otherwise they exhaust their local resources and just end up sitting around.

My dream is to build an agent fleet that can go into someone else's universe, replicate like crazy and be hugely successful, and completely take it over. Muhahahaha.

I have loved this game since I got it.

The game is a simple and fun top-down space shooter with the ability to design and fly your own space ships, and even design an entire fleet with ships ranging from small shuttles and fighters to large destroyers and frigates.

There are several different races (some of which you can't play) that unlock while playing (and destroying stations from a race you haven't unlocked before), each with their own technological pro's and con's, but they are all (reasonably) evenly matched, and where one race falls short in say shield technology, it makes up for armor or speed.

The universe is generated in sectors each controlled by the majority of whatever ships are in that sector, so it can at times be hard to claim a sector completely when there is just 1 little core still floating about. The universe is limited in size, but thats alright since flying over one edge of the map puts you at the opposite side without a teleport or cheap backend trick. Watch out for pirate fleets though; These are, from what I gather, uploaded by other players and are randomly selected, which means that in one universe you may find ships you won't encounter in the next. This uploading is done through anomalies called wormholes that allow you to upload your fleet (designs) or fly to another universe. The latter will generate a new universe for you while you keep your resources, credits and ships.

The only downside I experienced so far is not being able to destroy core blocks from certain stations. Usually this happens after a few hours of playing and may be memory related, but other than that it plays like a dream. The thing about player created content worries me a bit though, but we'll see how well balanced the game is over time.

A definate recommendation and big thumbs up for this gem.

Let be break this down into a few categories. Graphics, Sound, Story, Controls, Gameplay. I will end this review with my honest opinion after just about 30 hours in game.


Graphics:

The Graphics for this game are simple. And that is what this game's charm is riding on. 2D. It is simple, but because of this, this game has a very good feel to it. Like games of yesteryear. The game, with it's simple graphics. also has much diversity in the way it presents said graphics. From lightly colored tints, to bright shades. With the geometric shapes, the games has as much variety as you give it. And if you allow yourself to become immersed, the game will provide the rest.

Sound:

I'm thinking of deleting this game just because it's so good that it's distracting me from everything else. 10/10 probably one of the best designed games ever

I haven't been into gaming much in the last few years.  If I touch my laptop it is usually for coding, writing or producing music.  That all stopped when I got this game.  It seems like they thought of everything.  Every aspect of the game is polished and to the point.  This will be your universe.
This game is the reason I have slept for only 5 hours over the past three days. It is difficult, it has a fantastic soundtrack and it is a buckets of fun.

I bought this game a couple days ago, and am having a lot of fun with it. I especially like the idea of being able to send my fleet into another persons game (of course you have no actual control over them while they are in there) I find that interesting, seeing another person's set of ships while exploring. That's just the one thing though, the gameplay if extremely fun, and despite me dying over and over (hey i'm not that good okay?) it is just so entertaining. I would definitely reccomend this to anyone who enjoys something that's sandbox/arcade.

Beautiful and deep.

The designer did a good job making the exact configuration of your ship very mechanically relevant.  You can spend hours thinking about where to place your thrusters, armor, turrets, ect.

The progression isnt bad either- there are 12 factions, each with many parts to unlock.  Its hard to describe how different it feels going from a faction that lets you make things out of squares to a faction that forces you to use rhombuses instead.

Fighting player made fleets is also pretty awesome.

The minigame of Can you make a ship for X points that beast everyone elses ship that they spent X points on" is actually really interesting and deep as well.  Watching the AI pilot your ships is quite interesting (though its a shame there isnt a more formalized way of pitting your designs against specific friends' ships).

This game is basically a better
date: more fleshed out version of the spore cell stage."

reviewText: Awesome game and suprisingly tight soundtrack

In theory the game is about 2D space battles.

However I spend most of my time designing and building my ships - and that involves a great mix of planning, experimentation and working with the different fleets strenghts/weaknesses & shapes.  That part of the game feels a lot like the board game galaxy truckers to me.

Reassembly is an extremely fun, addictive game. It has a pretty unique concept that was executed really well.
If you like spaceships, expansion, customization, dogfights, big ♥♥♥ (faction) battles, factions, or just nice things in general, you should get this game.

Pro's
+ Addictive
+ Infinite customization
+ Expanding is fun
+ Massive battles
+ Several unlockable factions
+ Asynchrous multiplayer
+ Has more depth than you think
+ You can make your faction exactly how you want it to be


Cons
- Once your faction is unstoppable, there's pretty much nothing left to do
- Other players sometime make huge spamming death machine ships which they then release into the wild, meaning they can pop up in your galaxy too. Might take over your galaxy.

This game exceeded my expectations by far.
The way it does ship creation makes it similar to StarDrive, except way better, in everything from the possibilities to the quality of the editor.

The camera pans with a weird delay, sometimes your ship wont be anywhere near the center of the screen.
Friendly AI really likes to ram you head on, sometimes they dont even attempt to avoid.
Asteroid fields are too dense.
The game generally gets bad due to crowding when theres too many ships, although the efficiency of the engine is very impressive and it takes a lot to make it lag.

But despite those things, if it gets an FTL mechanic and multiplayer then I'd give it a 10.

This is a simple game.\nThat is not to put it down, out of a lot of games this is by far one of my favourites, some of the factions are a bit limited, However that does not take away from the unique experience that this game offers.
A touch rough around the edges, but a really fun ship-building system! Definitely get this if you want to custom-build your ships, from intercepters all the way to gigantic capital ships!
An amazing game! I really love this game because its a new experience every time I play with so many factions to choose from!! :)
I have been waiting for a space building game like this for all of my life. Very fun to play around in.

Oh god, I can't stop playing this. Spore in space?

In Reassembly, you start out as a little ship which is just a minion of the station or carrier which spawned you. you collect resources and bring them back to the station in order for the station to make more allies to fight with you. each time you do this, you get credits which you can use to upgrade your ship and buy new part. Once you get big enough, the roles switch. You get to a point where you get a part which lets you spawn ships. your resources now go to making your own fleet which follows you and fights for you. Those ships will also bring you the resources they collect, allowing you to make more. If you put enough storage on your ship, you can even spawn the massive stations which intially spawned you in the begining.\n\nI love the game and it never gets old. There is always a new ship or even fleet to fight. Just as you think you have built the most powerful ship, an agent comes in and kills you and your fleet in seconds. This makes it so that you have to tweek your own design in order to compete with the new foe.

This game is really fun, for the 5 minutes I've gotten to play it. It gives an error and crashes every time the game runs, sometimes at startup and sometimes during play. No help is to be found for the issue.

A couple of things that have influenced my life reappear when I play this game. Stratosphere for the PC, Legos and the joys  of a summer backyard.  In this game you design a ship to participate in a large open world ship combat ecosystem.  You'll find joy at upgrading your ship and will look back on early designs and laugh at your lack of ambition.  It's satisfying to create a ship that fits a certain combat style.  Ship designing utilizes a clean workspace that is powerful. Amazing, coloful visuals and an epic electronic/ambient soundtrack also make this a great experience.  Pick up your destroyed pieces and get back into the war. 10/10. Recommended.
A must try. My newest favorite, just can't stop.
Build a ships and pit them against the AI. Simple game that twill eat time like crazy.
This game has a really nice meta singleplayer feel along with the feel of struggle that I have come to love in rpgs.

I had some high hopes given the video, and I'm going to put more time into this, but there are games that do this better.

It is much too hard to distinguish between allies and enemies.

There is definitely a steep learning curve, so casual gamers be warned.

I'm not going to say avoid this game, because it's clear that there's a lot of fun to be hard here by a person who has time to get over the learning curve. I would also say that the premise behind the universe is excellent too.

Gimbal is a similar game with better ship building mechanics, so I recommend that if you're looking for more casual play. It is a multiplayer game (singelplayer with bots) and the community is friendly.

A surprisingly simple to grasp, yet complext mastery system for such a fun game.

Space combat with geometry designs, in a fun atmosphere of grinding. No real story or concept to grasp, just build, expand, explore and repeat. Surprisingly gripping for such a simple dynamic.

The system works well with just basic resources to collect by destroyed ships or slowly harvested from a strange organic plant-like space stuff, convert it to credits for the faction you play as to grind and level up to unlock new parts and materials to build and design with.

Graphically its surprisingly impressive for such simple mechanics, and I've only had a few sparce occasions of which there was too much to render at once, slowing my rig down.

All and all, a worthwhile game if you are into building and designing your own spacecraft in a simple 2D top-down shooter.

Build ships, shoot enemy ships, gather recources, make money, build bigger ship.



What more could you want???
The designing process is different from what ive experienced, the time i've spent playing this game ive only found enjoyment.

For all enthusiasts of lego or/and subspace this will bring back memories. Create your own perfect space fleet and send them to  other people. It was much fun when i had to defeat player agents. The music is also great if your a bit into electronic music and the graphics are refreshing.\n\nControls are difficult to learn/master and had to tweak spaceships a lot to be usable (adding engines).
Nice to build ships, then blow up other peoples creations.\n\n

A great 2D space game leveraging a simple but versatile geometric ship-building system. You and your fleet blast and farm your way across the expanses, which are densely populated with both dev and player-made hostiles. It's not multiplayer, but the opportunity to share your creations with others, and pit yourself against theirs gives great replayability.\nWith a bunch of playable 'races', each with their unique build palette, and a spot-on musical accompaniment, this is a game you'll enjoy sinking time into... A lot of time.[7.0]
Super fun! Haven't even had it for 3 days and it already ate two of them!

The game is fun, and I love the customization. You have to build your ships to match your environment, and play style/skill. The battles are intense, and very frantic at times.



But then there are agents.



An agent in this game is another player's fleet, uploaded and ugly. The problem with agents is two fold:

a) They are usually better equipped than you are.

b) They actively destroy your stations/territory.



Agents suck. Make it a priority to destroy them. Leave, harvest, min max, eradicate.

This game is an awesome starship building/destroying sandbox. It is open ended, there are no goals. You build a ship, kill ships, gather resources, unlock parts, raise your ship size limit, build bigger ship, kill bigger ships, build something insane, die, try egain :-D Killing an enemy capital ship unlocks that faction for you and you can use it in your next save.

Graphic style is simple but looks very good. It is colourful and trippy. I would describe it as a space Lego on acid.

Sound design is ok. Nothing mindblowing, nothing bad - it works and doesn't pull your attention too much.

Music is great. It helps you to immerse yourself into this space madness. It will get you into some kind of trance and then you realize, that this game managed to devour your whole evening :-D

If you need story and goals, this is not a game for you. But if you like to build crazy things and test them in combat + you like 2D space combat games, you will love this thing.

This game is 1000% authentically fun, no gimmicks, no bull. The concept starts out very simple, but you find yourself in something simplistic becoming rich, detailed and thought provoking. This is a return to better days of gaming, modernized.
A Great Top-Down Mount&Blade Warband In Space Action.
Great top down ship building game. collect resources, and a interesting multiplayer aspect.

I'm going to make this review short.
Graphics 8/10-Simplistic, yet very fitting for a 2D space sandbox.
Building 9/10-Fun and intuitive spacecraft building.
Mechanics 10/10-Awesome and cool-looking reformation of spaceships, no game-breaking bugs.
Gameplay 10/10-Dogfighting based on skill and fleet battles that feel like they are real.
Overall 9.5/10-A great experience that is fantastic for the people who like to be creative, and awesome tournaments.
Worth the $15/$19.
Gotta love it.

I love this game. Spent hours, no days building and optimizing spaceship designs. This is a designer's game.

Pros:
-The controls are flexable so you can fly however you want, a very welcome feature in these top down 2D games.
-The attention to detail in physics is incredible, e.g. if your ship has no off-axis thrusters, it turns really slowly.
-Open ended - no one strategy to dominate. You can go for speed, armor, shields, range, or build cost. Or you can just be a farmer or a gatherer.
-Multiple races - just when you think you've optimized a ship series for a particular race, you can play a different race with different abilities and different parts!
-Really pretty
-Self-building ships: the trouble with other building games (e.g. StarMade) is that you always have to rebuild your ship after a battle. In this game you don't worry about that, although there are design strategies for having your ship regenerate faster.
-Good combat AI, so you're not frustrated with the AI pilots being idiotic which breaks many other games.
-Ability to customize the build sequence of allied ships and stations

Would like to see:
Fleet vs fleet battles with the asynchronous mulitplayer! There are ways to do this with the sandbox but it's not very accessible.
Better (maybe customizable) combat AI: e.g. turning the ship to hide damaged armor or shields from enemy fire while it regenerates, or maybe being able to specify a preferred range of engagement.
Better non-combat AI: Having AI ships being more exploratory would be nice, otherwise they exhaust their local resources and just end up sitting around.

My dream is to build an agent fleet that can go into someone else's universe, replicate like crazy and be hugely successful, and completely take it over. Muhahahaha.

It's a top down space shooter sandbox, and what an impressive sandbox it is.  The construction element of the game is really impressive.  My hat is off to the developers, they have accomplished something really impressive with reassembly.  I hope that it inspires developers everywhere in the future.
really a nice game""

reviewText:
This game rocks. It sucked me in completely for a couple of weeks. I'd look up at the clock and think omg it's been 6 hours! I'd go to work the next day on 5 hours sleep. It stirred my gamer blood! The ship building freedom is top notch. You build any kind of ship you want particle by particle and there are lots of smart, handy features in the ship building editor to save time. You can hold down the mouse and drag it across an area to select multiple components or you can just double click one piece and everything attached to it will be selected.

A quick ship building tip is to just build one side of the ship, say a wing, select all the pieces then hit c to copy. Move the cursor to a blank part of the screen and hit v to paste, then hit m to mirror (to invert the selection). Now you can just attach that perfectly mirrored section onto the opposite side of the ship if you need symmetry like for wings.
Symmetry is also important in placing your thrusters. You are in space so your ship isn't going to stop moving unless it crashes into something...or you put thrusters pointed in the opposite direction to the direction you're traveling in so you can break!
Also each different playable faction has some unique pieces to build with. Sometimes the minor differences aren't obvious, like where pieces don't have as much mass as other factions or they have slightly higher armor, but when you stack all those pieces together into a ship then the net values really make a difference in speed, toughness, or resource carrying capacity. You'll want to look at the stats on the ship pieces closely if you're into ship building.
If you're not into ship building there are premade ships available with each faction that you can use and just modify to your taste.

The game is beautiful to look at and very organic. To me it looks more like the world under a microscope filled with living, evolving organisms than it does a space frontier. Much like organisms, the ships actually create children. You can set a creation queue for yourself once you have a factory as part of your design. But you can also go into command mode by hitting tab and click on an allied vessel that has a factory and drag child designs into their queue so you begin to shape the future of your factions expansion without actually managing the execution. Just hit tab again to go back into pilot mode and go on your way. The allied ship you just programmed will now create what you set for it via the AI.

Once you've got your perfect fleet together you can find then fly into a wormhole. You will be given an option to follow it or stay. If you stay a parallel version of your fleet will upload to infect another player's galaxy through one of their wormholes while you remain where you're at with your original fleet. I just really wish there was some way of knowing how successful these invasions were, like a scoring system players could access to get some sense of how good your designs were.

The tournament mode doesn't pit you against other players. It just lets you test your own ships against your own designs and a small selection of premade designs. I would love to see a true tournament mode where you download player agents and test your ship against theirs with scoring. The game lacks true player interaction in real time but atleast we can see other player's creations as they come into our own galaxy as enemy agents controlled by the AI.

Unfortunately I do think there is a balance issue that needs to be addressed with faction 4. You will eventually find certain enemy agents that are typically oblong, travel at high speed, and shoot enormously long particle rays at you at range even from off of the screen! That's faction 4. They almost made me rage quit because they really get too many advantages, but I perservered and went back to the design editor. Their weakness is maneuverability. Their big bad weapon of choice is not turreted so the whole ship has to turn to target you with the death ray. This is not a huge disadvantage because their ships are inordinately fast but if you build a ship that can quickly side step their line of fire and either swarm them or ram them so that they can't turn into you then you can take them down...if you can catch them. Trapping them against asteroids is a typical ploy. Really though, no other faction gives nearly so much trouble...

The only other criticism I have is lag. No it's not really just a hardware issue. I play many other games where it's not an issue. The devs themselves have stated that they've worked really hard on the optimization but the fact is there comes a point where there are so many collisions going on in the galaxy that it can be taxing. I have an i5-4670, 8G ram, nvidia GTX 780 so my hardware is good. But I like faction 2 whose strength is cultivating resources and building up a fleet really quickly. Once I push out a bunch of ships that then create their own AI controlled child ships, the game has alot to track. The devs said to go into options and lower the physics updates per second value so I'll try tweaking that more. But it kind of makes me want to put the game aside now and come back later, maybe playing a different faction and not use a swarming strategy. If you get lag you can also follow a wormhole to a fresh universe, but that too can start to get repetitive.

The fresh content is really about fighting other player designs as enemy agents enter your galaxy. I hope the devs continue to work on the lag issue (maybe instancing parts of the playing field to lower the amount of AI activity needed as the game progresses). I'd also like to see them expand on player interaction by scoring invasions, and maybe add some simple tiered goals with rewards for flipping sections of your galaxy to your faction. I think those things would add alot to the game's longevity for me. Regardless, this is a really creative game. I love looking at it and playing it. It was worth every cent.
Very good game...it lives...somehow ;-) Must have! Trust me, go buy it.\n\nPersonal rating is a 8.5 / 10

Reassembly is a fantastic game! It's a pretty looking, lego-like game, that lets you build your own ship from a measly fighter to an unstoppable jauggernaut capital ship. There are quite a few unique factions to unlock and build with that are all pretty fun to play as with their own special weapon types and building blocks.

Although I full heartedly reccommend this game I think it's important point out some gripes.

End Game Is kinda boring
-Reassembly is one of those games where you become so powerful that there simply isn't strong enough competition to personally test your work of art against. There are some fleets you can battle that can be difficult but often times they can be really easy.

Faction Economy and territyory system isn't fleshed out
-Gaining and losing territory seems very ambiguous and pointless beyond %100 conquering the map, which is tedious and time consuming. There doesn't seem to be any benefit of having territory. You're supposed to give resources to ship building factories that will then go out and gain territory, but this is kind of un-engaging past bringing the materials in.
-There aren't really any capital" territories that faction forces are strongest at. Having these would bring in some depth to the world
date: adding difficulty and strategy to your campaign. Attack the capital of a faction and cripple it's economy so it can't reinforce other territories as easily. Some factions have cargo ships that don't really do anything but get killed by you for some free money. Giving them something to do that has benifits would be amazing for this game.\n\nBeyond anything I've mentioned the game is a great time! If you're even slightly considering picking this up
recommended: do it! Especially if it's on sale."

Great open-world shoot-em-up with a fantastic modular ship design system. I could (and probably already have) spend hours just designing and testing out different ships. I've played it for hours and there are a number of things I really like, but I'm going to focus on the areas that need improvement for this review:

My biggest complaint is the lack of end-game goals. Once you reach the upper limits of ship size and amass a big fleet, there's pretty much nothing that can stand in your way and the game becomes trivial. At that point, even if there wa s a win condition, there's no real reason to keep playing.

One of the other areas I'd like to see improvement in is the various factions. The first faction, Terran, has a lot of different technology to play with, but most other factions only have a few different weapon types, etc. This made playing the factions I'd unlocked less fun than I had hoped.

Finally, the ship AI leaves a bit to be desired, specifically their ability (or lack thereof) to navigate around obstacles. For a game set in space, the world is densely populated, and I've frequently had issues with AI ships getting stuck behind asteroids or accidentally getting latched onto other ships (the more irregularly shaped ones). Even trying to turn your own ship around in similar situations can be difficult with the default control scheme (mouse rotates ship).

What an amazingly brilliant game.  I have to applaud the creators, I am nothing short of blown away.

Its intuitive, incredibly original, and has a ton of content.  The physics engine is phe-nom-i-nal.

BUY IT. BUY IT NOW.

Reassembly is an interesting game, with many possibilities for building. The developers have managed to blend simplistic graphics with complex gameplay mechanics, creating a unique gaming experience which can not be experienced in many other games. Also, the recent introduction of modifications and Workshop support has made the game even more creative and community-based. Finally, the developers have created an interesting tournament mode, so those players who enjoy massive space battles will be drawn to this game too.\n\nAll in all, this game is brilliant for anyone who enjoys franchises such as Star Wars and Star Trek, and those who love a challenge or just a laid back session of messing around.

reviewText:
I started playing and before I knew it, 5 hours had passed. This game is fun & addictive. It's a strange mix between bullet hell shooters, real-time strategy and Spore (the species evolution game).

Build & customize your ship, research new building blocks, add on a factory, start producing ships for your fleet, build space stations, conquer the map. This last bit... tough!

The ship builder/designer is a game unto itself. Construct a ship by taking your command module and attaching blocks to it. Armor blocks, engines, power generators, harvesters, automated turrets, manual fire weapons, missile launchers, drone launchers, etc. Then press the test button and watch the AI duke it out in an arena against 5 different ships with similar construction cost in 1 vs 1 battles. It will highlight strengths & weaknesses... and it'll give you more information on how to further tweak the perfect ship.

I think I spent over half of my time with this game in the ship builder and battle simulator. It's just so much fun!

Wow.

This game is phenomenal. A true gem. It's like a rabbit hole that goes far deeper than you would assume at face value.

There is a lot of hidden depth in this game, from the simplistic yet very rewarding ship construction to the different ways varying races specialize, such as farmers who can cultivate plants into resources as opposed to annihilating all who oppose them with gigantic rail guns.

The game also boasts aesthetically beautiful fully destructable ships and environments, and a gorgeous soundtrack to boot.

In a lot of ways this game has me thinking this is what Spore should have been. Only with living spaceships.

Buy this game. Support awesome developers.

I just purchased this game, and I am already blown away by everything. This games' controls remind me of ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS, in sort of a spinny, out of control type of way. Thats what makes it fun tho. Would definitely recommend. 20/10

This game also has a very unique difficulty, where you have to experiment and use your imagination in order to be successful. I truly can't wait for this game to grow and reach great heights.

reviewText: Taps straight into my need to tinker/experiment and refine, without dissolving into the usual option-paralysis that build&fly games usually have with endless numbers of components or useless decoration.   Love the simple artistic style, the ambient music and mostly intuitive building interface.   I still need more practice with flying.\n\nThe only negative I can think of is the over-zealous 'auto-zoom' feature, which is easily disabled.

Arcade-style graphics.

Design your own ships.  The part shapes are just occasionally odd enough that getting things to line up becomes part of the fun.

Test designs by letting them autopilot versus random other designs.  Center of gravity and healing rate are important.  Some ships are practically a huge gun with a seat and thrusters strapped onto it!

I spent hours not even playing - just designing a ship and watching it play against other designs in the test phase.

Once you are happy with a design (or just want to shoot something yourself) go in and harvest resources where the bad guys are, which also allows building up a fleet to team up against opponents.  Building a fleet is pretty cool - although they are something like a herd of cows...  not too smart and they get stuck in the weeds sometimes.  Playing the fleet dynamics is a whole game by itself!

The flight is very space-like where you have to oppose thrust to slow down, which makes it feel very swimmy (I think why they say welcome to the tide-pool).  In that regard it feels a little like Spore's bacterial stage, only flying takes much more concentration.

Replay value is sky-high, as optimizing ship designs at all size allowances allows starting over and trying new ideas.

Also, the game feels very different than other games because you have complete control how your ship handles (although once it's damaged and your engines have fallen off it will handle very differently until it heals again over several seconds, relatively fast).  Trying to control a damaged ship reminds me of Robocraft, though this game is much more twitchy.


TLDR:

If I had to pick a favorite game so far in 2015, this might be it.  The gameplay is straightforward.  There are always more things to want to try out, which takes time to get there and try them.  And Space feels alive.  This is more of a tadpole simulator than a space game.

The game I've been looking for. Reassembly is easy to understand, rough to master, with multiple different ship construction strategies that may or may not work, whether alone or together.
Your objective is to collect resources to upgrade and build your ship(s), eventually providing your ship with a factory block that can spawn a fleet for you. Enemies are generated off of other players' designs, copied through the use of wormholes, keeping you however from ever encountering real players, just AI versions of their fleets.

Pros:
-No frame drops, I've rarely been lowered in video quality throughout my time playing
-Expansive maps, plenty of sectors generated swiftly with new stations to capture and factions to fight
-Comfortable building interface, with useful tools like mirror and copy and paste to make everything much faster to build, putting you in the fight sooner, plus a lot of weapons and tools to make specialized ships like drone swarm spawners, rocket carronades, snipers, etc.
-Nice artstyle. Very minimalistic, but it is still nonetheless fun to watch your ships reassemble" as the new parts are traced and come to life in the middle of a battle
-No loading screens. Literally none.
-Test feature
date: which pits your newly made ship against another of the same value to test its strength in a real battle
recommended:
before you try and fly a space dumpster into a battle and waste time

When I first saw this game being played, it reminded me of fish in an aquarium, just with the ability to shoot lasers at each other. Even now, after I know it's a space game, it still has that organic look.

This is a great game. It runs very well on an older laptop, and when things get too intense with the graphics, the program simply steps down speed rather than crashes. The design interface for the ship editor is very well done and you can zoom in and out. It has a lot of things you can use, but just enough so you do not get overwhelmed from too much inventory to choose from.

Piloting your ships is a little tricky, since it involves the cursor and the keyboard and even then you have settings to choose from. My best analogy of piloting a ship in Reassembly is like riding a horse, where you use rein to control the speed and steer your steed.

The conquer the universe mode is pretty straightforward and you got lots of time to build up resource. The tutorial helps you get things rolling though I was hoping for more, like for example what exactly am I scooping off these asteroids? To date, I've never been wiped off the map for being too slow. If you beat an agent, you unlock a faction to play.

THe sandbox mode? Okay, that's the first real negative on this game. I'm old enough to have played games that involved you using complex commands in a text editor  to create the scenerio before the game began, so let me tell you I've never seen a sandbox mode that involved command language since the 1980s. This would have been acceptable for the 1980s but this is the 21st century, and most computer users are not programmers. They would expect an Activision-esque style of interface where you select number of players, difficulty level, type of victory scenerio and so on. AFter seeing a dazzling UI, asking the user to create a sandbox match using command line languages gives this game a unfinished look. It's not a deal breaker. I got more than my money's worth out of it, but I would have loved to see what the sandbox mode was like.

My verdict? Worth it, lot of replayability value and you will have hours of fun designing things and watching them go blooey. Just skip the sandbox mode.

Let's talk. Sit down. We're here because we care about you. Now we need to talk to you about your problem. Pick one from the following list.
- You bought Reassembly.
- You have not bought Reassembly.

This game is that sandbox you played in as a kid. While most people were playing GI Joes and army men, you were pretending that firetruck was a star destroyer. That Tonka truck was a Carrier. This game is that sandbox, and that Carrier is real.

Anything in your mind can be made in this game. Do you want to build unrealistic space gods that spin at 2000mph while sneezing death? Do it. Maybe you want to build a true to design Star Destroyer, or the BattleStar Galactica? I've seen CIS Control ships, the Serenity, a Borg fleet, and a literal pirate ship with tiny whale escorts. If the blocks fit, you can build it. And the blocks always fit(not).

As for actual mechanics, this game starts you out as a tiny little fighter. You destroy enemy ships, reactivate defunct friendly stations and gather resources. These resources allow you to upgrade your ship, until one day you too can build a battlecruiser the size of a small moon. You can also produce your own fleet, which can in turn produce its own fleet or follow you into combat or both. There are tons of ways to play the game, and little things you will find that feels like your own little trick.

TL;DR: This game is too much fun. You will get addicted. You will stop playing, and then come back and splurge another 50 hours on it after you think you forgot about it.

P.S. To whomever has been on the receiving end of my 190+ ship fleet dumps the last two days, I'm sorry, but I need your galaxy. Enjoy the SuperCap, 20 frigates and 170 teeny fighters :)))))

Played this game for many hours outside of steam. This game is quite enjoyable, relaxing experience. Take your time to build ships however you want for whatever roles are needed - go out and expand your territory, or if you are like me and favor the Farmer faction simply populate surfaces with plants and watch as your fleet size grows. Of the very few down sides to this game is a lack of detailed instructions on the part functions ingame (you basically have to memorize them, learn from guides and videos posted by others). Some in-game mechanics are also lacking documentation (such as how to restrict building of ships). All the lack of documentation issues generally don't add up to much problem once you have played a faction for some time however.\n\nOverall a very good game and an enjoyable experience. Definitely worth the purchase if you like building stuff and seeing how well it performs.

i am a strategy/survival/creative game lover. I like games like minecraft, terraria.  I personally don't like fps or space shooter games which looks like this one.

I pick this game to try couse it was offering that u can create your own space ships.  I saw that not only you create your own vessel but you create an echosystem actually. In this game everything acts like living beings they grow, they sperad and claim territories. You are the lader of the echosystem. You design how your faction will do acually by altering the designs. Game AI uses your designs if you have suitable one for a stuation.  If you don't, they have their own designs. Your resource also a space plant which is growing spreading around like your faction.

You start with a pre-designed faction with its own unique blocks and weapons. Simply you gather resources and grow to be better, stronger and dominate a huge map which is infinite like with its wormholes. You design your own ships with limited blocks at start and vary them by researching more which gives you like infinite combinations. Game also helps you with this by its pre designed ships.

i strongly reccomend this game if you define yourself like me
Awesome :)\nPlenty of fun !

If you were into to building space ships with legos or drawing them as a kid(or do as an adult) you will get to bring them to life with this game.

I have sit down to play this for a little while only to realize once I am finished a few hours have passed.

There are 7 unique factions to choose from and some others made by the community. I haven’t tested any of those community ones yet so I cannot judge those.

There is a bit of a grind to unlock all the different parts for your ship but the reward of using those parts to design the craziest, strongest or just silliest ship you can is worth it. Fighting fleets designed by other players(AI controlled) known in the game as agents is the most fun way to test those ships. The test option on the design screen is probably the truest test of them though. Basically your ship fights someone else's design around the same point value both are ai controlled.

How much time you will spend playing this is really based around how fun you find designing. So if you are the type of person who will spend hours creating characters just to see if something will work the way you think it's probably a good game for you.
Simple and satisfying ship construction, deceptively tactical combat, this fulfilled a very old craving of mine.\n10/10 would reassemble again.

Pretty fun until you try to collect all the other races.

It should be possible to disable tutorials, when you try out a new race though.

Despite these minor drawbacks, really fun time playing!

Reassembly is a very simple game, you are a ship for a faction and all other factions are enemies; that doesnt sound too different to most games; although the real point of the game is the fact that you can build and design your own ships. This mechanic is very well implemented and the game is really fun, flying round space blowing stuff up really never gets old. The building ship feature is very, very good (it could do with some fixs and some more variations), everything on the ship is down to you if it is too slow thats your faut (add more thrusters) or its just getting smashed against flagships and agents (add hull and shields) you can change it and upgrade it to fix these problems. Everytime you die there is something you can do to imporve the ship, you learn from every mistake and can adapt to it. There is something about this game that just brings me back to being a 5 year old playing with Lego and trying make HUGE planes and space ships. Really great little gem of a game.\nTL;DR Great little gem, lots of replayability, buy if you have ever played with Lego.

The game features infinite ship customizational freedom with each part to the ship being in sections of small blocks, so you can create whatever you wish.

Basicly my favorite game ever. Ya build ships n' shoot stuff. What more could you ask for? (Multiplayer (SHHHHHHHHH))

Only thing is, it's early access so be expecting bugs and unfinished content.

Nonetheless... WORTH. EVERY. PENNY.

this game benefits from the following:
Extremely addicting gameplay; an easy to use shipbuilder; a simple, yet appealing art style; an amazing soundtrack; diverse enemy ships; the ability to battle with other people's ship fleets; and a vast modding community.

that said, it can sometimes get annoying when every single agent (Player-designed fleet) comes after you at once before you're ready. (but don't worry you can exact revenge on them soon enough)

it would also benefit greatly from multiplayer, which, if it were to be added, might bump it up next to other big multiplayer games.

Overall, I highly reccomend this game to any who like Space, LEGOs, and blowing things up for money.

reviewText:
Wonderful game. You design your own ship from parts and other building blocks, in whatever configuration you want based on those parts(I do wish there were more parts.), build more ships, have the ships you've built build more ships exponentially, and generally take over the entire universe slowly.

If anything, I'd liken Reassembly to a more fleshed out version(Though as far as I know there is zero connection.) of the freeware game Warning: Forever. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warning_Forever

It's great.

Fun little game. I liked the idea, the gameplay and the possibilities.\n\nIf you are looking for something to play this weekend, you might consider buying Reassambly. But don't expect this game to be addictive as hell.

It starts off with a nice 3-20 hours of playing before you have done it all, then it's all about building new ship designs, and flying them around in arcade mode.\n\nI'm building new ships with my daughter, she loves it. The biggest problem is that the parts are not symetrical so while things look good you can have a real hard time to make them fit together. Also while you get to play against the ships of other players, there aren't that super many of them around.

Very fun space combat/ship builder sandbox game. Spawns fleets created by players (and spawns your fleets in others' games) to give a ton of variety. Different factions also increase replayability. Very minimalistic on graphics, but there's enough explosions and such to keep me happy. Performance suffers a bit when there's tons of stuff on the screen (like drones, missiles, etc). Also got super annoyed by the auto-zoom" feature zooming at the worst time until I figured out you can turn it off. Could use clearer tutorial/instructions at the beginning. I got stuck trying to figure out how to increase my P limit for too long IMO.\n\nOtherwise

reviewText: It's great.  Less than a week by this point and over 55 hours clocked.  If you like desiging ships, be them silly or serious, this game will reward you.  It's fun to design and test each vessel and all while your faction adapts your designs and tweaking designs is easy and intuitive.  The AI is okay, but it's major strength is your own customization.  It has high replay value and if you want 100% completion on any one game it's tough as nails.  It's exactly what I look for in a video game.  You get out of it what you put into it.
So addicting and fun it made fallout boring to me!!
Great game. Each of the factions feels unique and the replayability is amazing.

One word....  addicting.  Two words, challenging.  I love the sound track as well which is quite relaxing, and helps with the frustration of the challenge of the game.  As a kid, me and my brother used to draw depictions of various space ships with their special weapons in mid battle.  This game is like being able to participate in that battle real time.  Brings back memories and makes it very difficult to stop playing!  XD

If you are hesitant on if you should buy this game or not. Buy it! I've owned the game for a week and have already play 16 hours. As many other reviewers have said this game is very addicting. Starting as a small ship the size of a VW Bug, and then destroying other faction's ships and harvesting resources to become a ship the size of an aircraft carrier or 5. On top of that, your main ship can ♥♥♥♥ out other ships that you've designed, which will attack what you've locked on to.\n\nAnd once you've had enough with one faction, you've unlocked others you can now start a new campaign with. Other factions have different strengths and weaknesses. Buy it.

I started playing and before I knew it, 5 hours had passed. This game is fun & addictive. It's a strange mix between bullet hell shooters, real-time strategy and Spore (the species evolution game).

Build & customize your ship, research new building blocks, add on a factory, start producing ships for your fleet, build space stations, conquer the map. This last bit... tough!

The ship builder/designer is a game unto itself. Construct a ship by taking your command module and attaching blocks to it. Armor blocks, engines, power generators, harvesters, automated turrets, manual fire weapons, missile launchers, drone launchers, etc. Then press the test button and watch the AI duke it out in an arena against 5 different ships with similar construction cost in 1 vs 1 battles. It will highlight strengths & weaknesses... and it'll give you more information on how to further tweak the perfect ship.

I think I spent over half of my time with this game in the ship builder and battle simulator. It's just so much fun!
Asteroids + customizable ships + a lot of steroids = Reassembly

Very addictive spaceship building, battle and capture game.

It's a constant challenge even later on in the game - just because of the infinate possibilities of the spaceship builder. This is an easy to learn yet very deep game with a lot to offer.
Don't be put off by the simple 2D visuals, the gameplay and building will suck you in. Give it 2-3 hours and you'll be hooked for weeks.
You can lose track of time pretty quick when you boot this up.

If you're a sucker for design-it-and-fail kind of games (like I am), then this game will be the crack to your addiction. The simplistic parts that you get to design your ship with is all you need to create the coolest looking space-ships this side of the galaxy. It's not as simple as plug the device on and go"

reviewText: This game is epitome of everything I tried accomplishing in my early childhood imagination. Building as you would with lego's is a small aspect to this game. The ability to create magnificent creations, throw some lasers, hundreds of missles and guns on it, is very fun. Just having a sandbox game with these features would have been good enough for me, but it goes on to provide an engaging universe full of objectives and threats. This game also has a very unique difficulty, where you have to experiment and use your imagination in order to be successful. I truly can't wait for this game to grow and reach great heights.

Extremely enjoyable and addictive. I really like crafting ships in a way that truely changes how it behaves with sort of old school Master of Orion garphic style reinvented. Not a hugely indepth game compared to a 4X but what it does, Reassamble does very well.

Wow.

This game is phenomenal. A true gem. It's like a rabbit hole that goes far deeper than you would assume at face value.

There is a lot of hidden depth in this game, from the simplistic yet very rewarding ship construction to the different ways varying races specialize, such as farmers who can cultivate plants into resources as opposed to annihilating all who oppose them with gigantic rail guns.

The game also boasts aesthetically beautiful fully destructable ships and environments, and a gorgeous soundtrack to boot.

In a lot of ways this game has me thinking this is what Spore should have been. Only with living spaceships.

Buy this game. Support awesome developers.

This games' controls remind me of ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS, in sort of a spinny, out of control type of way. Thats what makes it fun tho. Would definitely recommend. 20/10

If you loved playing with or building lego space ships as a kid, then this is probably your dream game. It's a little hard to get into at first, but once you understand the mechanics of what is good/bad on ships, and how to maintain growth within your faction, then the game becomes a joy. Also if you're a perfectionist you can spend hours upon hours just building and testing ships. I know I have.

Honestly one of the flat out coolest games I've ever played. The whole feel of the game, how it's organic yet futuristic and simple yet extremely complex is just awesome to me. It's a game that invites you to show off your creativity and ingenuity, and really makes you proud of your progress and what you've achieved no matter how far into the game you are, even if you're already been there in a previous save. Easy to learn, hard (but extremely fun) to master. Well worth the 15 bucks, would highly recommend.

reviewText: It's creative, it's relaxing and it's fun! Thats all you need to know.

I must say, I don't come back to games that often.
But this is one of those gems that I can't leave alone for longer than a week or so, it's a masterpiece.

The idea? Make a ship, blow up other ships, farm resources, make an army, use the aforementioned army to destroy other ships and make your faction inevitably powerful and build super destroyers, for the sake of entertainment.

But it's so much more than that, it has beautiful graphics (even on lower settings), doesn't destroy your framerate, allows free building of pretty much whatever you want, in terms of ships / stations, the only part of this game that I feel is lacking is in both the modding and sandbox areas.

They could use a little work, not for me, but for those inexperienced in the usage of command lines.
Aside from that, if you like action/exploration, then take up this game, i've had 90+ hours on it and I'm still not bored.

Great game. Each of the factions feels unique and the replayability is amazing.

If you are hesitant on if you should buy this game or not. Buy it! I've owned the game for a week and have already play 16 hours. As many other reviewers have said this game is very addicting. Starting as a small ship the size of a VW Bug, and then destroying other faction's ships and harvesting resources to become a ship the size of an aircraft carrier or 5. On top of that, your main ship can ♥♥♥♥ out other ships that you've designed, which will attack what you've locked on to.\n\nAnd once you've had enough with one faction, you've unlocked others you can now start a new campaign with. Other factions have different strengths and weaknesses. Buy it.

It's great.  Less than a week by this point and over 55 hours clocked.  If you like desiging ships, be them silly or serious, this game will reward you.  It's fun to design and test each vessel and all while your faction adapts your designs and tweaking designs is easy and intuitive.  The AI is okay, but it's major strength is your own customization.  It has high replay value and if you want 100% completion on any one game it's tough as nails.  It's exactly what I look for in a video game.  You get out of it what you put into it.
Really fun. Find my self spending heaps of time trying to build the best ship i can :P:D
